description:
I categorize this restaurant as a Chinese restaurant catered to Chinese Americans that came over to the states in the 1950s through 80's 

Another one of my Richmond district spots. You will usually see big groups of 2nd generation Chinese people here . Hence I like to categorize this restaurant as one of the last Gum SAn (golden mountain) restaurants .  Meaning food that was cooked for Chinese Americans with a taste of Cantonese cooking that transformed into Americanized Cantonese food from the 70s-90s

I think the food taste better for dinners especially weds nights opposed to the lunches . 

We usually order the chicken salad , there's two we get the cheaper one it's better.
The stuff chicken with sticky rice is good when you have a bunch of people.
The steamed salted egg with pork is a hit or miss.
Oh the salt and pepper pork chops are tasty but sometimes they give me salt and pepper spar ribs and they are smaller . And they don't tell you. :(
The salt and pepper chicken wings are good as well
This place gives you house soup .
The chow mein and chow fun are tasty .

Servers have been here for ages so  it's good to get to know them .

Also for big parties I recommend getting a winter melon soup,

This is one of the last  golden mountain restaurants so enjoy them now because once they're gone this type of food and restaurant will be lost !!!!!!!
author: Jenn C.

description:
There were ten of us for a ten course banquet. I wasn't a fan of the ginger crab or the crab and mushroom soup but everyone else raved  about it. The salted crispy chicken was amazing and had msg on the side for those who wanted it. There was a delicious squab lettuce roll, braised beef over baby bok choy (my favorite), a shrimp and scallops dish with mixed vegetables and ginger, and some relatively innocuous noodles at the end. 

I'm leaving something out. Oh -- the warm tapioca soup dessert was delicious. 

We also had Peking duck and it was succulent. 

Service was good. There was no corkage fee for the wine we brought but that might have been an exception. 

It's waaaaaaay out on Geary. Worth a trip.
author: Tim P.

description:
This outer Richmond district outpost is almost a non-Yelp venue (local spot, not fancy, and something you don't want to share with non-natives) as it is already packed with the locals who know this place.  This is one of those Chinese family style restaurants that caters to mostly banquets of families and thus rarely if ever do I see non-Asians eating here on their own.  In fact I don't think I've ever paid for a meal here because usually I go here when my mother wants to take my family out to dinner.

We came here on Christmas Eve and it was packed.  We had reservations so we were able to get our table.  Parking was a little easier because of the holiday, but you often need to parka few blocks away.

We usually get a nice Westlake soup, their chicken salad, fried spicy chicken, some fish with mixed vegetables, some noodle dish, lettuce cups  and drinks for 11 people and it comes out to around $60.  What a deal!!!
author: Erik H.

description:
The 7 Of us had lunch here
After our golf game at Lincoln. We ordered double orders of everything. Started with the chinese chicken salad. It was huge and It was delicious!  It was freshly made and very crispy. I could have just had that
For lunch.  Next came the hun Tao Yee foo won Ton. It was big too but i managed to finish my bowl. The won Ton were big and meaty too!  Then came the curry tomato beef geen mein or crispy noodles. My favorite dish of the meal. There was plenty of crispy noodles and I tasted the curry!  It was yummy and it took no time for us all to finish it. Next came the beef chow fun with bean sprouts. It was okay. I like mine wet so it is as tasty but there was leftovers.  All in all, you can't go wrong with this place. Each of us paid $18 for lunch which for the quality of food was okay.
author: Donna L.

description:
Kirin has been around for quite some time. My parents used to tell me it was all the rage in the 80s. Flash forward to 2018 weekends nights, this place is still booming. 


The lunch menu is a steal. Big portions + soup of the day. The other day I enjoyed Kung Pow Tofu w/ white rice!  So delicious! 

Some favorites include: 
Spinach and garlic
Dry sautéed green beans 
Any type of chow fun 
Sweet and sour soup

You honestly have to know what you're ordering to enjoy a meal here. It's under your discretion if you get a mystery meal or want to try something new. You can't go wrong with a classic dish.
author: Shannon M.

description: FAM FAV!!! English translation = Fish salad, fried wonton soup, snow pea sprout leaves (?), giant clam (silver vermicelli noodle).. seafood clay pot.. and peanuts to go they're that good
author: Briana W.

description:
Reasonably priced Cantonese lunch. Good service, but food was meh.  Possibly we did not order their best dishes, but the dry fried beef chow fun was recommended by the waiter.  We also had wor won ton which was flavorless and shredded chicken chow mein which was good.  We did not like the raw bean sprouts on the chow fun.  And the heavy amount of grease in the bottom of the chow fun platter was not appetizing.  I did notice the "wok hei" that another reviewer mentioned, but an appetizing stir fry smell cannot overcome a dish that lacks flavor.

Portions were generous but food was really mediocre.  As other reviewers have noted, the interior is a really tired '80s look and needs a good cleaning.  This restaurant was really popular in the late 80s and early 90s.  It seems stuck in a rut, although the chef from those days has passed away.
author: Joanna S.

description:
We've been ordering to-go from Kirin for some time now and have always found their dishes to be hearty and the container almost struggling to contain things within, so when we came for an actual sit down dinner, we were definitely a little more than disappointed at what we found.

We ordered a variety of dishes:
Sticky Rice stuffed in Crispy Chicken - this was literally sticky rice stuffed inside Crispy Chicken SKIN. There was not one piece of chicken meat in this order. For $45, it's definitely a unique twist on a dish but hardly worth the price in my opinion. (3.5/5)

Seafood Stir Fry with Mustard Greens - mustard greens were on point, they were crisp and not too bitter. Seafood (though only shrimp and scallops) were also decent in my opinion, but overall, the plate was small. (4/5)

Black Bean Cod Filets - WHERE THE FISH? This dish is literally onions and bell peppers sauteed in black bean sauce. (0/5)

Braised Lamb in Clay Pot - decent flavor but many pieces were tendon or tough to chew. (3/5)

Pea Sprouts with Dried Scallop - slathered in gravy, my favorite vegetable became almost inedible because of how salty it was. (2/5)

As an additional note, for a Saturday night, this place was dead. We walked in at 6:30pm, there were 3 tables sat and we left as the only table in the restaurant. Somewhat telling, in my opinion.
author: Elaine Y.

description: Chinese chicken salad is the best plate they have.  Winter melon soup is also a good choice. Otherwise yea it's an ok place to eat always busy but you can normally find a spot. Good for a family dinner
author: Jonathan W.

description:
You will get alot of different Chinese food you wouldn't find anywhere else. It is very Cantonese in style, and I wouldn't way I'm a huge fan. 
- The wonton soup was by far a favorite, the meat inside was really delicious. Everything else that came afterwards... not so much. 
- The butterfly shrimp was bacon wrapped around shrimp, but fried to the point that the bacon tasted like hard cardboard. 
- Fried quail: definitely never had this before. Crispy and tasty, more game-y than chicken and much less meat. 
- Mandarin pork ribs: sounded delicious on the menu, but we hardly touched this. It came out cooked with a bright red-pink sauce, too sweet and tasted a bit floral. It was just really strange tasting.
- The beef clay pot: expected there to be more taste to this dish, but I guess it was just classic Cantonese style clay pot, in a sort of bland tasting stew (texture was tender, though)

Overall, kind of disappointed. Probably best to go with a large party and order the chicken stuffed with sticky rice (which is $42 and everyone here raves about) in advance
author: Ke C.

description:
My family on both sides have been coming here for years.  Kirin is primarily a go to for banquet dinners.  There are some several smaller tables set up along the side.  We typically end up here eating off the banquet menu.  The walnut prawns, roast peking duck, and stuffed tofu are all good.  But the real winner here is the crispy chicken stuffed with sticky rice.  It's like crack!  The skin is so crispy, the sticky rice is sweet but has just the right consistency from being baked.  And it doesn't have any of the IMO gross black mushrooms and dried shrimp like most sticky rice.  Get it!  

Service is fair and prices are cheap.  Just writing this review makes me want an order of that chicken.  Who wants to drop an order off in the Peninsula for me?!
author: Cat C.

description: I'm a sucker for Mongolian Beef, even at those food courts at the mall. Kirin is across the street from the divey bar of Tradr Sam's and I may have been known to order $100 worth of Chinese food because of scorpion bowl consumption. But I digress. The Mongolian beef over rice is my favorite and has the perfect amount of spice and sauce. Not too salty or oily and you can add extra meat by $1 increments. It comes with the crispy noodles and if you're feeling really hungry, throw in some of the walnut prawns. Nom.
author: Marie C.

description: I ordered Yang Chow Fried Rice tonight. It was very good, and the price was reasonable ($10.80 including tax). I have ordered here over the years, not a lot, but sometimes. I was moved tonight to see the same faces I saw twenty years ago, when they were younger. Everybody has been there for many, many years, and that is nice.
author: Robert H.

description: Good food but the presentation left a little to be desired. Also the red plastic chopsticks were hard too see on the red tablecloth and were too slippery to grab the mu shu pork or the abalone.
author: Brian H.

description: I like the food at Kirin. My favorite is Fish Salad. Price is reasonable. Service is good!
author: Thomas H.

description:
Old-school, authentic Cantonese restaurant that serves Cantonese dishes not found elsewhere.  This place has been around for decades.  I remember going here in the mid-80s and the place still looks the same.  Don't expect a fancy, modern restaurant but do expect good food with top-notch service.  The waiters wear nice vests and actually serve you.  Best service so far for a Cantonese home-style restaurant in the avenues.

For a Wednesday lunch, we ordered ala carte, family-style, and had:

Hung Tu Yee Foo Won Ton Soup - not made in many restaurants as this soup is labor intensive.  The Won Ton is fried first then added to a Westlake style seafood soup that has minced crab, BBQ pork, egg whites, cilantro, etc...

Chinese Chicken Salad - lots of fried won ton skins and red ginger.  The waiter will parse out onto small individual dishes rather than deliver to the table and leave.  I guess I am used to serving myself....nice!

Salt & Pepper Fried Fish - large, tasty, slices of fired fish.  The fish was fresh and the fried outer layer did not get soggy over the course of the lunch.

Twice Cooked Pork Belly - another large dish.  Could have benefitted from more fermented red bean curd paste.

Did not order but if you have a large party, we saw old school dishes of Fried Whole Deboned Chicken Stuffed with Sticky Rice, Winter Melon Soup, etc...

Go here for traditional Catonese cuisine with excellent service.  The waiter bagged up our leftovers rather than just bringing us take-out cartons.
author: Scott L.

description: Very good Chinese food. The Hung Tao Yee Wonton, Minced Beef and Egg over Rice, Pork Lard with Lettuce over rice, Walnut Prawns, Mao Tao Tofu "Spicy", and Clams with Black Bean Sauce are  delicious dishes.
author: Edmund L.

description:
We attended a lunchtime banquet as part of a group of 14, mostly Asian.  Our first impression was that the place looked a bit tired: duct tape on the door handle; some torn chair upholstery; worn carpet; a restroom cluttered with chairs and equipment.

Another member of the party, who had recommended the place, took care of the ordering:  about a dozen courses from one of several banquet-menu options (listed prices ranging from $289 to $549 for a party of ten, with larger groups like ours presumably proportional), though there was apparently some room for negotiation over substitutions.  The food was more impressive than the room.  Everything came to the table hot and with good timing, placed efficiently and unobtrusively on a lazy Susan.  Highlights included crab egg drop soup;  chicken salad; shrimp lettuce wraps; sautéed prawns with peapods, sprouts, and mushrooms; salt and pepper chicken; broccoli and mixed vegetables; bok choy; whole crab; whole fish; Mandarin spareribs; wheat noodles with mushrooms.

The inevitable liter of 7-Up and bottle of Martinelli cider  on the table.  Limited beer selection:  Tsing Tao, Heineken, Bud, Sierra Nevada.  No hard liquor.

With tax and tip, our party paid $30 per head.

Metered street parking is available on Geary, at $2.25 per hour; meters take credit cards.  Two hour limit, but meters can be fed.  Parking on nearby side streets is free if you can find it, but still subject to a two-hour limit, which I'm told is enforced.  Served by the 38-Geary bus from downtown; nowhere near any BART station.
author: Alan F.

description: Came on a Sunday right at 11:30 and it wasn't open yet even though the sign says it opens at 11:30.  The table was sticky and the seats were old with ripped cushions, and it smelled like cigarettes.  The food was pretty good though, a bit pricy for a neighborhood Chinese restaurant.  We ordered the salt and pepper chicken wings, it was really juicy and cooked just right. The wings were big and meaty.  We also ordered the shrimp fried rice which had tons of large shrimp and it was really good.  The beef chow fun with black bean sauce and green peppers was very tasty, and the asparagus with chicken was excellent.  Forgot to mention that our meal also came with complimentary soup.  It was a seaweed soup which was very tasty.  The only reason I can't give this place 5 stars is because of the sticky table and ripped up seats and bad smell.
author: P G.

description: This review is solely for the Hung Tao Yee Won Ton soup.  I haven't found too many places that make it and am so happy to have found Kirin.  I order it every time I come to SF and it tastes great fresh and reheated for late night snack/breakfast leftovers.  I usually just get it to-go and I haven't had anything else really so I'm not sure how their other food compares.
author: Jonathan C.

description:
I've been eating with my family here since birth, and I've really only seen families eating here, too. I've been eating here long enough that I didn't know the name was Kirin... my cousins and I refer to it by hr owner's name, Henry's. Don't come with a small group - go big and go banquet style. 

This is an old-school Chinese restaurant that's been around for ages, so it is crowded on the inside (especially when so many families are eating here) and service can get a little scarce sometimes (but it's usually not bad since there's usually table service with serving food). Try to get ahold of the main guy, Henry, and you'll be well taken care of. 

I'll be honest - I have no idea how we go about ordering food here. I think my relatives order ahead of time so we get the banquet style dinner (and a table), but I'm actually not super sure... but I can totally tell you which dishes are best. 

1. Fried quail here is the bomb dot com. Always perfectly seasoned and crispy, and always a consistent size. 

2. Order ahead and get the off-the-menu stuffed crispy chicken with glutinous rice. It's basically sticky rice inside of the most delicious crispy chicken skin. This is hands down one of my favorite, favorite things to eat, enough that we've started ordering two platters of it every time my family eats here. 

3. Lobster noodles here are great - the lobster is a little more seasoning-heavy and greasy than a seafood joint (such as Newport Seafood down in LA), but the noodles here are way better. Trust. 

4. With so much heavy food, get a soup, too. The winter melon soup is always good, IMO, and usually comes before the heavier entrees. 

Overall, this isn't fine dining, this isn't the best food you'll ever have, but it's homey and it's family style. Bring a (large) group and spend some good time catching up and eating.
author: Cat D.

description:
I really like this place.  I've been here plenty of times and never go wrong with it. This is my grandfather's favorite Chinese restaurant in the city, in my opinion its way better and less greasy than anything in Chinatown SF.  It's a ways out of the city proper but the parking is better.  Pretty decent service for a Chinese restaurant as well.  

Pretty decent size as well as relatively clean.  Which is always a big plus for me.  I feel like this is a place where I would stop by if I was craving something.  Their jellyfish salad is pretty good as well as their winter melon soup... MMMMM... and you can't forget about the Jalepeno Fried Chicken... the bomb.
author: Cliff S.

description:
Darn. Right when I found a place that made good chow fun and scrambled eggs I find a roach in the food.

We ordered take out last night and ate some of the food, but saved the rest. My mom was reaching for leftovers but found a dead roach on the bottom of the container. 

Not coming back.
author: Guilliana J.

description:
Felt like having some Chinese food on the way home from the North Bay. Took a chance and gave this place a try.
Crab & Corn soup was delicious with generous amounts of crab. Mu Shu pork was as good as any I've had. The only dish that fell short was the vegetable chow mein. The Veggies were fine but the noodles did not make the grade. Soft and not as tasty as I would like. 
Other dishes looked appealing as I checked out other tables.
I would return to explore other dishes.
author: Ric W.

description:
My family had our annual Chinese New Year dinner at Kirin earlier this month. As always, my family selected a set menu for our group of 30.

*Chicken salad
*Lettuce cup
*Winter melon soup
*Peking duck
*Chicken stuffed with sticky rice
*Walnut prawns
*Fish
*Mushrooms and bok choy
*Yee mein
*Taro and tapioca dessert

My favorite was the peking duck, but only because I love roast duck. The skin wasn't crispy as a peking duck should be. I just enjoyed the meat. Their special winter melon soup was beautifully presented. But taste wise, it was a little bland. The fish was good, but slightly overcooked. Disappointing since this is normally my favorite dish. The rest of the food was pretty average.

I had fun celebrating CNY with my family, but the food was just A-OK.
author: Elena N.

description: The place looks a bit run down but the food is SO good here! It's tasty authentic Chinese food!  I would definitely eat here again and again!
author: Donna L.

description: Had the Giant Clams w/vermicelli, "Hung To Yee Fu Won Ton (deep fried won ton soup), garlic snow pea sprouts, seafood claypot & their fish salad
author: Rowland W.

description:
Super authentic Chinese food, one of the better ones in the city. I would definitely come here more often if it wasn't on the other side of the city. 
The lobster noodles can not be beat here (believe me I've been trying to find some place closer) 
If you order at least a day ahead they make the best crispy sticky rice stuffed chicken (best English translation I could come up with)
We've never ordered anything on the menu that disappointed. 
The staff is super nice and hella attentive even when the house is full, pretty much every time I've gone. 
Parking can be a pain but worth it.
author: Blake R.

description:
Really, really solid food.  I grew up eating Chinese food in the Richmond district and I have eaten at most of them.

My father and I go out to lunch once a week.  When he asks where I want to do, I often ask to go to the Kirin.

The food is always tastes great.  We usually get the rice plates, which are reasonably priced and generous portions.  I love the kung pao but I sometimes get other things off the menu, too.  The menu is pretty long and has a lot of choices.  If you ask, they will make sustitutions within reason.  (For example, my dad does not like onions so he gets broccoli instead).

The service is prompt but I would not exactly characterize the waiters as "personable."  That said, they get the job done.

Great place for really great Chinese!
author: Gary A.

description: Decent but not amazing. Had the family dinner for 6 plus pork hash, a traditional off the menu dish. The Chinese chicken salad was their best dish and the seafood soup with seaweed was good. The pork has was a disappointment with little flavor and poorly prepared. They also charged $10.50 for rice 7 people which is ridiculous and I've never experienced before at any Chinese place in the city.
author: Candace S.

description:
In a battle for the best chicken salad this place would lose, despite what my friends believe.

These are the same friends who think that Panda Express is delicious, authentic Chinese food.

Came here with a group of friends because they said I had to, I must, I couldn't miss, this place's chicken salad.

First of their "rainbow chicken salad' should be called "wonton bits and fried noodles salad."

Actually there was hardly any chicken or lettuce. So, how this could be a salad I'm not sure.

But all the tables around us ordered two and three orders of this stuff.

I thought it was very vinegary and bland. 

Oh, with tons of peanuts.

I guess if I were an elephant I would love this place. 

We also had their winter melon soup, which was just average. It didn't have the nice seafood I'm used to, and instead they went with chicken broth instead of abalone and all that good stuff.

Their tofu pot and beef stew were also average. The spices weren't memorable, and their beef wasn't super good, but it wasn't bad either. Just average.

In the end, my friends asked if they could have my chicken salad, so I said "Sure, knock yourselves out," and slid the plate to them.

I was glad to be rid of it, to be honest.
author: Jack R.

description:
KIRIN gets a * * * * FOUR STAR rating based solely off of one dish...

The HUNG TAO YEE FOO WON TON

It's a fried won ton, but not the typical American perception of fried won ton, it's a full won ton that is lightly fried.  Then it's put into a thicker soup, with real crab meat (not a lot, but enough to give it added flavor).

It's a "Must Have" and "Go To" dish to have, I'd say to "share" but in truth, one bowl for $7.50 is perfect for one person and once you start sharing, you'll regret giving others some of the Hung Tao Won Ton, and wish you'd ordered your own.

It's a great dish, rarely found at many restaurants and even if found, isn't often executed and delivered perfectly as they do at Kirin.

Everything else here I've seen and had have been average, nothing awe inspiring, but nothing offensive to complain about either for the most part.

KIRIN also has BELFAST CIDER, those San Francisco Chinese Americans who grew up in the 1970's and 1980's remember going to wedding banquets and seeing the Belfast Cider (used to have a white label over a glass bottle with gold lettering) along with a bottle of 7-Up and also a bottle of some sort of alcohol like Cognac in the middle of the lazy susan turntable at the large tables that seat 10.

The service here is fast, and typical of Chinese restaurants, sometimes overly friendly other times a bit disinterested, maybe it's cultural as well as linguistic barriers, but regardless, the job gets done and service is really contingent upon person to person and their personalities more so than a blanket statement of the restaurant or the people as a whole.

Parking is fairly easy, 'tho meters are $2.00 per hour, so 8 quarters gives you 60 minutes, and if you use nickles and dimes on SF meters it sometimes seems they don't give you the right proportionate amount of time and you might get gipped by the meters.  If you're willing to walk, there is neighborhood non-metered street parking that can be found, especially this far out of the Richmond and away from most of the busy retail areas.
author: Rick S.

description: Food was great, but they over charged, and when asked about it, persisted in charging us for the giant salad when we had the little one. We took their word for it, but later realized what had happened. Just a buzzkill.
author: Kris F.

description:
A neighborhood restaurant that's been around for decades and keeps the locals coming back. A no frill type of Chinese restaurant which means prices are reasonable and portions are huge! Restaurant is pretty small but quite a few large tables - perfect for any of kind of "celebratory" Chinese dinner. You can make a reservation as well. 

I came for a birthday celebration recently and my friend's dad chose this particular restaurant. They are regulars and really enjoy the food. I wasn't too familiar with this area (Outer Richmond). Parking can be tough so prepare to walk a little unless you get really lucky. 

We had their popular Chinese Chicken Salad which sounded weird at first because first of all, Chinese folks don't really EAT salads.  They like their greens cooked, hot, and saucy. Turns out there actually isn't any lettuce in it (LOL) but there plenty of yummy chicken, wonton strips, peanuts, etc. Almost every table ordered one of these! 

Our group also had a crab and corn soup, honey walnut shrimp, snow peas and beef, and lobster YEE MEIN. All the dishes were flavorful, well portioned, and delicious. Lobster was pretty decent size - definitely didn't feel ripped off. 

Overall I had a solid experience here and would come again if I was in the area!
author: Johanna L.

description: This is one of the best cantonese Chinese restaurants you'll find in SF. The food is excellent and the service is the good as well. We've been eating here for years. It's the kind of good ol' cantonese food we were raised with. Everything is well prepared and consistent.
author: Susan W.

description:
It takes a lot for me to write a 1-star review, in this case it's because this restaurant is no longer sweet - it's sour (and it's not just about the pork.)

It is however about the chicken. 

Kirin used to be one of our three go-to's in the Outer Richmond.

Last night here's what happened:

1. They asked if we wanted the Cashew Chicken w/Rice (new to me, but the price was right.)
2. When I got there to pick up my food they said that "Someone else took it and they'd make a new one."
3. 10 minutes later a new one appeared.
4. When we opened the bag we found 50% Cashew Chicken and 50% rice - barely enough main dish for two people.
5. The chicken was a bit tough and fatty.
6. The cashews were stale.
7. The carrots were undercooked.
8. It tasted bland at best and that's being nice about it.

We will be contacting the restaurant directly about our experience.

Seriously, this was the worst chinese food we've had in years. And now that I noticed their health rating is 84 out of a 100, we won't be back.

Come on Kirin, there are a TON of Chinese Restaurants on Geary and quality counts. 
Back to the Tsing Tao and Hunan Cafe 2 for us!
author: Dennis S.

description:
I recently came here for a family dinner and was looking forward to a couple of their signature dishes.  My parents had pre-ordered the menu and most of the dishes were the stereotypical dishes, but the two that I was looking forward to were the winter-melon soup served in a winter-melon and the sticky-rice stuffed in deep fried chicken skin.  I was disappointed by both dishes.

The winter-melon soup was very bland and the chicken chunks in the broth were severely overcooked.  The melon flesh was very soft and the melon collapsed without the support of the melon flesh as expected..  

The sticky-rice that was inside the deep fried chicken skin was also very bland and the chicken skin was very crisp.  The pieces of the dish where cut into large non-bite sized pieces, so you could only eat the components of the dish separately without making a mess.  Imagine sticky-rice sandwiched between two very crisp pieces of chicken skin that are not bite-sized.  If you try to take a bite, all the sticky-rice falls out because the chicken skin is still intact and squeezes the sticky rice out.

All of the other dishes we had were decent, but I doubt I'd be back to this restaurant anytime in the near future.
author: Wilson K.

description: The Chinese food here is downright awesome!! Not only is the food absolutely tasty (their stir fries have a delightful wok hei flavor and their large clam and cellophane noodles have a wonderful fresh seafood flavor), it's quite photogenic too.  Everytime I go here, there's always a large party celebrating an important event like a birthday or the annual extended family get-together. I can definitely see why-outstanding food with your loved ones is always a winning combo!
author: P C.

description:
Well, I was back again for another party. This time the Peking Duck was on the menu. This was one of the worst Peking Duck I have ever had!! The skin is supposed to be seared til it has a good crunch when you bite it. This was far from that. Instead it was mushy and no texture. The buns were OK though. 

Overall, this place is only good for a few items, the Fish Salad, the Oyster OR Squab Lettuce Cups and the Lobster Noodles. The rest of the menu is standard or below standard or way, way, way below standard such as the Peking Duck. If other places can make those few items then I would bet this place won't last too long.

Gee, I hope there are no more parties there for a while from anyone I know.
author: Rod W.

description:
After visiting this restaurant twice, I can say, it is definitely a great choice on Geary in SF. We've visited this restaurant twice now and the quality of food and friendliness of the staff is great! Sorry in advance.. no pictures because I was hungry and gobbled before it crossed my mind to snap a shot. Typical.

You gotta get the chicken skin with sticky rice. It's exactly what it's called. Imagine sticky rice, sandwiched within chicken skin. Oh so fatty, and oh so delicious. Apparently it's by ordering ahead only. So if you have a craving for chicken skin and rice, you have to order it 24 hours in advance. It's nice to try, so definitely order that if you get a chance. 

From the seafood to the soups, all is great. The fried wonton in soup is good too.. and I'm typically not a fan of fried wontons. The honey walnut shrimp is tasty, but they could go a tad lighter on the sauce. Talk about mayo overload. 

Dinner comes with almond jello or red bean. It's a nice surprise beyond the typical fortune cookies. 

Check this spot out!
author: Deanna G.

description:
For the fifth time, took my older son and daughter there for dinner. We always take a lot home for next day lunch or dinner. Menu is extensive. Among other dishes we had mushu pork, wow!! string beans with chicken, war won ton soup ,deep fried prawns wrapped in bacon, white rice and so on. Did not have the lobster with noodles this time, but it is a best buy in our opinion. I am 80 years old and have been abroad to Hong Kong, etc. not to mention all 50 States. I would rate this restaurant and the serving staff( very attentive to their customers ) at least 6 STARS!!!!! It is well worth the drive from Marin County to San Francisco to enjoy this dinning experience!!!!!!
Clifford R. Den Otter
author: Clifford D.

description: I've been going here for so many times. all the food that we ordered is always good. Would recommend it for those who wants to eat Chinese food. Love their lighting too.
author: Pia O.

description:
Starters: 

Chow mien was very bland, veggie fried rice was fair. Egg rolls were so so. They do not have scallion pancakes which was disappointing. They do not have anything to drink except sodas. 

Main:

Tofu dishes were pretty good (we had two of them with mushrooms). They were the highlight. Chicken dish was not good. The pieces of chicken were rank. It looked more like an octopus than chicken. 

Overall:

Staff was nice and family friendly hence the two stars. The food was a one star to my taste. It appears as though they just do everything as CHEAP as possible, especially the reject chicken. I would not eat here again. Sorry. I am going out to get ice cream now to cleanse my body.
author: Mike N.

description: Our go to place in San Francisco! Just had our wedding banquet there. All staff were dedicated to our guests. We really appreciated it.
author: Jimmy W.

description:
Kirin has very unique Chinese delicacies.  My group ordered:

(1) Eight precious jewels tofu clay pot
(2) Pan-fried minced "perpal" tofu
(3) Stuffed chicken with sweet rice

The stuffed chicken was incredible.  My group had never tried the dish before--sticky rice stuffed inside a chicken and sliced into large, bite-sized pieces. The chicken, which was cut and blended in to the sticky rice, was moist and flavorful.  The chicken skin on the outside was crispy and just the right amount of salty.  In addition to the chicken, we ordered a very unique tofu dish, minced "perpal" tofu. These were fried tofu pouches containing onion and other spices.  The eight precious jewels tofu clay pot was reliably delicious, as it had multiple types of seafood and mushrooms.  I thought the "perpal" tofu was a little too salty, but I really enjoyed the clay pot.

Not only was the food memorable, the service was, too!  After refilling our glasses of water and attending to our table, our waiters hummed their way back to the opposite side of the restaurant.  A couple minutes later, their hums progressed to full-on singing of Chinese opera. Free (unintentional) music!  We had some less pleasant auditory stimulation, too, in the form of the restaurant's telephone ringing off the hook.  This could be a good or bad thing, depending on how you want to look at it. On one hand, the restaurant is popular. On the other hand, the restaurant ambiance is shot because the telephone never stops ringing!

All in all, a very memorable meal. Next time I'm trying the bitter melon soup, which I hear is a must try item.
author: Brittany N.

description: I've been coming here since I moved to the Outer Richmond district. Now that I am moved away from this area, I still drive back here to eat. I think they have the most tastiest and original Chinese dishes. We especially love their Rainbow Fish salad, winter melon soup, and much more. Though, I think they are a bit pricy. However, it is all worth it. I definitely recommend this place to anyone who wants a taste of original Chinese cuisine.
author: Elaine C.

description:
My wife and I had a wonderful meal here. 

Service was quick. The waiter was helpful and spoke English perfectly. When the soup came, the waiter even filled our bowls with soup, noodles and wontons from the main soup bowl. 
My water was filled whenever I needed it, without asking. 5 stars for service.
The waiter made a point to wish well to every departing diner that he served. I made a point to give him a large tip because I was so happy with the service. 

The wonton soup had the wonderful Chinese soup taste that I grew up with in Brooklyn, NY., It was full of wontons and noodles and I loved sharing it with my wife. Five stars for soup.

The lunch specials, were all large portions, as I could see from the other tables and most were $7.50.  

We shared a beef chow fun, lunch special. A big portion and maybe more beef than I have seen at any other Chinese restaurant in the Bay Area. The beef was seasoned and tasted just slightly sweet and had a wonderful beef flavor. The noodles and everything else was also full of wonderful flavor.  All this and only $7.50! (5 stars).

Their sweet and sour pork was tender and also tasted delicious. Most Bay Area restaurants overcook their pork. This pork was soft and cooked right. The taste was just as I like sweet and sour pork. The portion was large and full of pork. 5 stars.

This restaurant was more like a neighborhood Chinese restaurant in NYC or Philadelphia than what I have experienced in San Francisco. They were like the old school Chinese restaurants that I grew up with in the 1960's. Their food was great and tasted similar to the Chinese food that I grew up with. 

This place accepts ALL credit cards. 

We had a wonderful dining experience there and we just did not want it to end.  This was Chinese food at its best. 
My wife and I will be sure to return this wonderful restaurant.
author: Steven G.

description:
Kirin, my favorite Chinese to-go place since I work in the neighborhood. Their portions are huge, the complimentary soup is always thirst quenching. It takes less than 10 minutes for the order to be ready for pick-up even during their lunch busy hour. 

Eating inside, one must try the chicken rainbow salad; filled with shredded chicken, fried wonton slices, and flavorful additions. The salad is my favorite appetizer! Great place with huge portions, delicious flavors!
author: Keith L.

description:
I've attended several banquet meals at Kirin, but not for a casual dinner. Recently, the four of us came here on Saturday evening for dinner.  Arriving before 6pm, we noticed that there were many tables reserved for banquets, but we were able to get a table in front of the restaurant.

Instead of ordering a pre-set dinner, we decide to each order one of our favorite dishes.   The dishes were:

Dried Bok Choy Soup - a pork based soup with dried bok choy, almond, and pieces of pork.  This complementary broth was tasty and a nice warm starter for our meal. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kirin-chinese-restaurant-san-francisco?select=FTWLjOb0WL1VftYlRubC6A#FTWLjOb0WL1VftYlRubC6A)

Clams in Black Bean Sauce - a generous portion of good-sized clams with some green peppers in a tasty black bean sauce with mince garlic. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kirin-chinese-restaurant-san-francisco?select=FTWLjOb0WL1VftYlRubC6A#60mMMTNhPaOJGDZ5dwU-2g)

Braised Lamb with Dried Bean Curd - served in a metal bowl, the sauce was tasty, but felt that the portion of lamb in the dish was small. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kirin-chinese-restaurant-san-francisco?select=FTWLjOb0WL1VftYlRubC6A#827eBpXKu5vXk4BONHKIyQ)

Rod Cod Fillet over Greens - Nice large fish fillet served over a bed of baby bok choy.  Fish was moist and perfectly cooked. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kirin-chinese-restaurant-san-francisco?select=FTWLjOb0WL1VftYlRubC6A#Ijowi2_bb35xqR-YhqPh7w)

Steamed Fresh Catfish with Black Bean - The thick slices of catfish were perfectly cooked and tasty with the black bean sauce.  Can you tell I love black bean and black bean sauce?  (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kirin-chinese-restaurant-san-francisco?select=FTWLjOb0WL1VftYlRubC6A#_XFMFKlPYP6LrfSqUOqRSg)

Almond Jello with fruit cocktail - complementary dessert, which was not overly sweet.  It was a nice finish to an enjoyable meal.  You had a choice of red bean tapioca as well. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kirin-chinese-restaurant-san-francisco?select=FTWLjOb0WL1VftYlRubC6A#Y0OLyinBqkYMM3pfBQpp8g)

Overall, food was very good and service was friendly and efficient.  Luckily we able to walk to the restaurant as parking in the area can be challenging.
author: Al L.

description: All the food we ordered was tasty. The large clam with glass noodles was delicious. My friends go there all the time and vouch for the consistency of the food quality.
author: Fiona M.

description: This place has very rude service and very bad food disgusting the sign said they were open till 930 I came in at 855 and and they said they were closed
author: Tony F.

description:
We were driving by this place on Geary on the weekend and decided to stop for a quick dinner. Initially the waiter did not want to give us a table. They only cater for large family groups on the weekends. We were lucky to get a table finally.
It looks like a very popular neighborhood place and the food was good. They are popular for their crab dishes and we also ordered a fish fillet dish.
I would recommend this place if you go with a larger group and people and they also have set menu which might work out economical.
author: Raman S.

description: We got special treatment from the manager. Don't know what our plates are called, we just ate. Our team sponsor ordered the food and I'm not sure if these plates were customize for the team. The plates are huge! Chicken wings are so good I wish I had more but knew they were greasy and we had Hooters the night before. All the food were so delicious especially the shrimp. I didn't want to use my hands to peel off the shell but I'm glad I did cause the shrimp was so good. Different from socal. After we finished the shrimp plate, the waiters brought out a bowl, with hot tea and lemon. Warning!!! It's not meant for drinking it meant for dipping your hands to wash off the seafood smell odor. Great food! Would love to come here with my family.
author: Lina L.

description:
Came to try out the restaurant. My family and I arrived around noon and the restaurant was super empty. There was one other party here besides us, so we were seated immediately. 

The menu is pretty pricey at first glance. NOT knowing what to get, my family and I just stuck to ordering off of the lunch specials. The dishes are fairly priced, $6.75-~$9.00 per dish. I got the chicken and broccoli chow Mein ($6.95), my sister got the pork fried rice ($6.95), my mom got the shrimp and beef over chow fun ($7.25) and my dad got (I think) the house special noodle soup (?) ($7.95). 

1. Chicken and broccoli Chow Mein - Salty!, not enough broccoli. But plenty of chicken, noodles weren't too bad but just a tad greasier than I like. 

2. Pork fried rice - very inconsistent dish. Some bites were bland and some were just eating chunks of salt!

3. Egg and beef chow fun - no gravy. It was pretty good, not too oily. Only downside was that the noodles were overall pretty tasteless. Nice amount of eggs and beef was good. 

4. House special noodle soup - came out to be seafood soup. Very little noodle to meat ratio. Soup tasted like cabbage soup. Okay overall. 

Now on to the worse part of the experience at Kirin....the service SUCKS! The waiters could care less about you! They look bored, they are lazy, and they are very, VERY RUDE. The bald, large waiter couldn't be any more impatient waiting for us to decide what to order after five minutes of sitting down. When our food came, the dishes were dropped off very sloppily and the waiter just walked away. My experience with the staff was awful since I would say 3/4 of the waters we encountered fitted the description I just gave. The other waiter was okay, the guy with the full head of hair deserves the tip, not the other guys. 

The food could be better and the service definitely could be a lot better. 

D
author: Alex T.

description:
Why We Always Go to Kirin for the Family's Chinese New Year's Banquet*:

1) A towering mound of Chicken Salad filled with pickled ginger, crispy wontons, and cilantro.

2) Flavorful diced chicken in lettuce cups with plum sauce.

3) Comforting winter melon soup served up in a huge husk and artfully carved.

4) The artery clogging favorite: sticky rice covered in fried chicken skin.  (complete with creepy chicken head staring at you!)

5) Duck with greasy skin wrapped up in a soft bun with plum sauce and scallions. 

6) Sauteed bok choy and mushrooms (my fave!)

7) Mayo covered prawns with sesame sprinkled walnuts.

8) A steamed fish dish that I had absolutely no room for.

9) A cup full of long noodles for long life!

*Usually in March.  Happy New Year / St. Patrick's Day!


40J
author: Amy C.

description:
The food as a whole is good.  And because of the good food, the waiting staff has developed an entitled status to the point that unless you pre-tip them, they will not provide service to you.  Unless they see or believe that you are "worthy" of them to kiss your behind, they won't lift a finger.

Management has been removed and do not see the real truth of the poor to non existence of customer care and service.

Things won't change for they had not changed their service staff for the past fifteen plus years.
author: Dennis Y.

description:
Having come here for over 25 years, I felt it was time to write a review on just some of the many items that I have had over time. Kirin has consistently has been a steady and solid performer for small as well as large gatherings of family and friends.

Soup:  Minced beef and parsley. simple and great on a cold evening.  The blend of beef and parsley is perfect as a starter. For those in your party that do not like parsley - ask them to place it on a side dish. winter melon soup is also one of my favorites as well. Either way, you cannot go wrong with these two items.

Appetizer:  Can you say salt and pepper chicken? Perennial favorite hands down. Love the garnish of the diced green peppers and green onions.

Beef Dishes:  Beef with broccoli, Beef with tofu, and Mongolian Beef. One cannot go wrong with any of these beef dishes.

Beef Chow Fun:  As of recently, this dish has come out with a burned "wok" flavored taste and for whatever reason - has not been quite what it has used to be.

Steamed Chicken with Ginger and Scallion sauce:  Oh so good and one that we usually order every time.

Peking Duck with Steamed Buns:  One can order this although it is not on the menu if you call in ahead of time.  Just wish that Chinese restaurants in general would bring back those large size steam buns from years ago instead of the tiny "mussel" shaped buns that are used now a days.

Salt and Pepper Sole:  Do you get the idea that I like ordering the salt and pepper items?

Seafood:  any of the various steamed seafood dishes that the waiters recommend should you want to try a fish item.

Service:  Has always been great and should you go on a regular basis, many of the waiters will recognize you.
author: Richard H.

description:
This place was super busy on Saturday night. It seemed like everyone ordered a banquet menu. We ordered a $250/table menu. The food was okay. Some of the items were unique from the typical Hong Kong style food.

What we had:
1) Chicken salad - HUGE salad! Wow. I couldn't believe the size of the salad. The salad was okay. Avoid if you do not like rice puffs or wonton skins. The salad had a lot of these.

2) Minced seafood lettuce cups - I couldn't tell that the stuffing was minced seafood. Regardless, I still ate it since I like lettuce cups. Avoid if you don't like the rice puffs.

3) Winter melon soup - This is another HUGE item! I've never seen a winter melon so big before. The soup was really good. It had a lot of flavor from the ham, mushrooms, melon, and the dried seafood.

4) Honey walnut prawns - Okay dish. I just liked the walnuts.

5) Sticky Rice Chicken - This was a cool dish. There was crispy skin from a chicken and underneath had sticky rice. I normally don't like to eat skin, but the crispiness was hard to resist. The sticky rice had some seafood and chicken.

6) Bok Choy with shiitake mushrooms - Typical Chinese dish.

7) Peking Duck with steamed buns - Avoid. The skin from the Peking duck was not crispy. It was a big pile of oil on the dish. In addition, there wasn't any green onions to put in the bun.

8) Steamed Fish - The fish was fresh and not overcooked. Good dish to try.

9) Dessert - Oranges and fortune cookies - I don't really count this as dessert.

Parking sucks. Just be at the right place and in the right time to get prime parking.

Reservations are highly recommended.
author: Jackie S.

description:
Very disappointing. They sat us close to the door and had to wear coats to stay warm. Service was slow.  Spring rolls were somewhat tasteless.  Mooshu pork was ok but the rice pancake was dry. The kung pao chicken was boring.  The beef and long beans..... The beef was grissly the beans were ok.  
Even the tea was off.  I have complained about the lack of good Chinese restaurants in Portland but all of Portland's Chinese places were better than this.
author: Bob K.

description:
This has to be the most sorry ass hell hole they call restaurant. This is not even close to pathetic chinese cuisine. Went there cause my 2 sis wants to eat there.I don't even know where to start no parking or the food taste like shit or the waiter r stupid.I would think if someone order some appetizer it would be serve 1st and soup then entree. But this place is serving food how the waiters want to.order deep fry squab but who would of ever expect to come out after the 5th entree is serve on the table. Until I ask the waiter that do u guys need to go hunt for the dam bird 1st the stupid waiter reply to me we wanted to wait until u clear couple of dish 1st well if u would take your head out of your ass and serve the dam bird 1st than there would not be any problems.Also my sis order Mongolian beef which her husban likes. To me it look like white ghost food..U know in the early 80s chinese food for white folks. 
I gave a look to my sis DO I LOOK LIKE A WHITE GHOST TO U.The worst of it all was the so call sweet rice chicken ( Law mi Gai ) this look more like sweet rice soup, does not even taste close to any sweet rice chicken. How can something so simple turn oout to be so shitty.
I don't even want to give review of other dish that we order  JUST put it this way total disgrace 
to Chinese cuisine.
author: Tommy M.

description:
My grandmother swears by their chinese chicken salad. 

The rest of the food was typical chinese food.... 

They didn't automatically give us a pot of rice, which I thought was weird.  We had to ask for it maybe twice before they gave us rice.
author: Kristin H.

description:
I must admit..this place is pretty good. We had low expectations since it wasn't as crowded as the other Chinese restaurants in San Fran on a Saturday night..esp on Memorial Day weekend. It isn't a fancy restaurant - just your normal Chinese restaurant. We were seated right away when we got here.

We ordered four dishes - sweet and sour pork, garlic pea tips, cod with black bean sauce, and half a chicken. We also had their fish maw and corn soup. All the food were tasty. They served fortune cookie and sweet soup for dessert. Relatively inexpensive Chinese restaurant. Took us by surprise since we wanted something really nice for dinner but everywhere were like a 2 hr wait!
author: Susie C.

description: Fresh. Low on msg. Friendly staff. Clean bathroom. Hard to come by when u go to an authentic Chinese restaurant.
author: Karatar A.

description: I don't know what happened to this place, by I used to come here all the time for family dinners. I went here a few days ago for another one and it was awful in terms of cleanliness. There was a lipstick stain on my glass. My napkin was dirty. There was hair in one of my dishes and when I took a noodle dish home, I found a metal piece of some sort. I can't believe they are able to operate under such disgusting conditions. I would not recommend anyone coming here or bringing any guests, especially family. Very embarrassing.
author: k h.

description:
Be careful on TOGO orders because they will over-charge you!!

I ordered a hot and sour soup and beef/vegetable noodles- was overcharged and on top of that I found a hair in the hot and sour soup. If the soup was 10/10 I think I would have eaten the hair but it was kind of bland and not so tasty. Noodles were not so bad but didn't really have any vegetables with them.
author: RayRay M.

description:
2words LUNCH SPECIAL . When asked what should I order ? What's my fav  dish ? Anything you order will be tasty fresh and filling . 
I worked in the area and frequented this place mannnnnnny times always thought it was funny when you ask them how long the food is going to be they yell through the phone TEN MINUTES!!!!! Love Kirin friendly staff  wonderful food
author: Adriana H.

description:
Gung Hay Fat Choy! Year 4710 on the Lunar Chinese Calendar. 
Year of the Dragon, my year! 

We came here like we did last year to celebrate Chinese New Year, and since Kirin is famous for its Fish Salad, that is what we ordered, a mountain of Fish salad! It was good! This is a dish that is increasingly hard to find. It is similar to Chinese Chicken Salad, but more refreshing and delicate. 

You have to come here early, otherwise the cramped family style tables get all filled up. We always come at 5:00 pm to insure a table. 

Other tips for those who are not Chinese, but eating with them:

The Chinese aren't big on pubic displays of affection, so the way they (older Chinese) show their love is through food, and lots of it! They usually over order, because it would be super embarrassing for anyone to not be full and satiated! 

Do not insult your hosts by not attempting to eat that strange looking dish in front of you! Grin and bear it!

And just like Amy Tan's Joy Luck Club taught you, you should politely refuse the first attempted offering from your host, wait for the next attempt, then acquiesce on the second.

And when the lazy Susan comes your way, you should only take a little and leave enough for the others, don't hog the dish like a Pig! It isn't your year anyway, yet! 

And even though the host denigrates themselves to appear humble, you have to heap them with positive praise when they do that, so they can appear even more humble! DO NOT agree with their self-inflicted deprecations, or you will commit a serious Faux Pas! 

All you Yellow Fever white guys dating Chinese girls better do your homework! OR you will hear a lot of Chinese chatter that is surely complaining about your White Devil poor manners! 

As typical, we had a ton of food with many other dishes besides the Fish Salad. Like minced pork lettuce cups. And beef chow fun. and many more. 

Kirin is also known for its Wintermelon soup, served in the rind. But you need to order this 24 hours ahead, just like you have to at most restaurants for Peking Duck. 

Last tip: Fight for the check, but not too hard. And thank your host profusely for the wonderful meal and the great choice of dishes.

And don't expect a Red Envelope.
author: Wanugee N.

description: I agree. Customer service is good and professional. What could be another Chinese restaurant in San Francisco has a nice menu with wonton, rice dishes, and noodle plates. We had fried wonton soup, rice noodles with egg and shrimp(eggs were abnormally salty), and beef curry with rice. I like this restaurant on Geary and would come back.
author: Denise C.

description:
Our family's go-to joint for large gatherings. Solid all around food. 

Mongolian Beef, chicken wings, bitter melon soup and tofu and mushrooms in oyster sauce were the standouts last time. The Tomato Beef Chow Mein was a bit too sweet and needed more of that ketchup taste. Oh, and of course, you have to order the Chicken Salad. It's not traditional or anything but it's darn tasty.
author: Eric L.

description: Family favorite place!  A little pricey but really good food.  Try the fried chicken wings and chicken salad.
author: Jackie N.

description: First time there with my family and we a big group.. About 12. Never been there before and was one of the few restaurants that are open at an odd time.. 4ish.. Not quite dinner time but we were hungry. Definitely a good place less the fancy and good eats. Wish that had seat us to use 2 table as it was tight to eat. The only minus.. Food was tasty and great Portions for family style.
author: Minna M.

description:
This was another Chinese New Year/89th B-Day event and I can honestly say one of THE BEST meals I've had in a long time. 

Old school here!

We're talking about dishes I haven't had in a long time and only at special occasion.

Raw fish salad- WOW what an amazing and refreshing treat before the meal. Light, clean and full of great flavors and textures. 

Squab lettuce wraps - some of the best I've had in a while. Squab tasted clean and not gamey wrapped in perfect crispy lettuce. 

Winter Melon Soup- I haven't had this dish in years! It was perfectly cooked, melon scraped off the sides, amazingly light broth and bits and pieces of mushroom and chicken. Perfection! 

Rice stuffed Chicken- Sticky sweet rice stuffed into a crispy de-boned and hollowed out chicken carcass. Words cannot describe how delicious this dish is. 

Peking duck with Bao - really do I need to say anymore?

Oyster, duck, pork with seaweed and fungus over lettuce - Dried oyster reconstituted with a deep grainy oyster taste, with fatty bits of pork and dark meat of the chicken topped with a xo sauce. Old school yumminess right there! 

Boy choy and mushrooms- the mushrooms were meaty and in a great sauce over steamed bok choy. Everything I love in my vegetables! 

Honey walnut prawn- yes an americanized dish but yummy and sweet nonetheless. 

Chow mein - long noodles for long life. Considering my Uncle was turning 89 I can safely assume long lives are genetic in my family case. 

Great meal and I will def be back!
author: Jade W.

description: This restaurant is beautiful, located in a nice shopping area right outside of Richmond with a open view of the kitchen it's very nice and clean.  And nice to see what's going on with the food from where we were sitting.  The reason this place only gets 2 stars is though the food is fresh it wasn't so good that I would rush back. Customer service was mediocre and they charge for tea,  which isn't customary for the many Asian restaurants I've been to before, and the .fortune cookies were stale.  :(  Also as we are sitting at our table less than 6 feet from the kitchen they started throwing the kitchen mats out causing dust to fly.  Major turn off.
author: Denise W.

description:
Can I just say how freaking amazing their salt and pepper chicken wings are? And not to utter blasphemy, but they're almost better than my Chinese mother's! Sorry, mom. 

Anyhow, their salt and pepper chicken wings are one of the sole reasons for my pride in my Chinese heritage. The batter is light and utter delectable! And the waiters always manage to bring them out to your table right after they've been cooked and are smoking HOT! So bring eating one, try not to burn your tongue and remember, it's all about blowing. 

On a side note, I'd also recommend their Fuk Kin Fried Rice. 

And if you plan on making reservations, they're required at least 2 weeks in advance, if not more. You're going to have to compete with those ginormous Asian families for your table.
author: Rebecca H.

description:
During my visits to Dennys Cafe & Hong Kong Lounge the last time on seperate days... I came back here once again to Geary Street and this time, I went to go explore Kirin Chinese Restaurant... This was another chinese restaurant that, I have been wanting check out as well and another thing was before coming to Kirin Chinese Restaurant, I remember reading a great yelp review from one my yelp buddy Cassie J and that's what made me come to this place... 

As soon as I got inside to kirin Chinese restaurant and when I looked at the menu, many many times in the past I have been eating Mince Beef W/ Raw Egg Over Rice to many timesso then... I wanted to eat something different so what I have ordered was the Steak Cubes W Tender Greens Over Steam Rice whixh I have not eaten in a very very long time and who knows how long...

When, I gobbled up the whole Steak Cube & Tender Green Rice Plate and I really liked how the way how Kirin Chinese Restaurant prepared  the Steak Cubes and the Tender Greens for me which both of them had a really great taste!!!
author: William B.

description:
All that is missing when I dine at Kirin is my couch and a flat screen smart TV.  I could sit for 24 hours chowing down this tasty food until I pass out in a stupor.

My bestie - who is Chinese - introduced me to this place.  I was told long ago when I came to SF that the best way to tell if a Chinese restaurant is a good one is to count the number of Chinese people eating in it.  Bingo.

The salt & pepper chicken wings are my Asian heroin.  I think in a food-off I could polish off maybe 50.  Hot & Sour soup: I could drain a bath tub full of that.  And the beef chow mein with Hong Kong style noodles......I just throw my head into it.

They are not stingy with the portions either.  Service is typically brisk - I walked in once and the waiter said 'What?' but I am just one lemming in the line and it's about the chow, I'm not dating the staff.

Yum - double Yum.
author: Casey C.

description: we ordered the 合菜，the food is quite solid, love how they cooked the lobster, quite tender and juicy.
author: Vivian Y.

description:
Food:
I've been coming here for years.  The food is always better than your typical chinese restaurant.  Nothing too fancy here tho. Like many, I like the chicken salad. If you need to try something new, come here to try the chicken salad. Its really a symphony of flavors and textures. Its cruchy, sweet, savory its just everything. Be ready to drop $30 for that salad. I think its called the rainbow chicken salad. theres a fish version, but i like the chicken version.

Atmosphere/Service:
Not the most authentic place by some. Some feel that there are not enough chinese people there, or there are too many ABC's (american born chinese) there thus its less authentic.  But im fine with that. I let the food do the talking. Chinese restaurants are not about the service or the atmosphere. Service is a step above most chinese resturants.
author: Jason C.

description:
I come to dine at this place minimally twice a year.
Favs: rainbow fish salad (raw fish), 
           boneless, deep fried, stuffed noh mai guy
           whole wintermelon soup (must order well in advance d/t cooking time)
           fried wonton soup (lunch menu) but they will accomodate for dinner

recommend: make reservations as this place can get busy with family banquets
the chinese name for this place translates as "9 Rivers Seafood Restaurant"
Kow Kong is an area near toisan, chungsan, fatsan, off the pearl river delta in Hoi Nam county, Kwangtung province. That's why this place has a lot of frog and fish specialty dishes.
i am a descendant from kow kong and my uncle who was raised in KK said the dishes on the menu are legit.

1 quirk: street parking only.... and it's in a residential area off geary blvd!
so i've elected to take the MUNI #38, exit 25th/26th avenue
author: Keikaikaoakua P.

description: Their rainbow chicken salad is particularly good and their chicken wings are the biggest I've ever seen. I've yet to taste one of their dishes and not like it. And the service is excellent, we've been regulars for years.
author: Alyssa L.

description: When I first heard that we had a way to eat here, (gift certificate,) I thought "Isn't this that "lobster noodle" place? I recall in recent memory walking by here many times and reading this restaurants "window specials." Everything seemed to be $29.99, including one of my favs, Lobster noodles. Actually, my knowledge/experience with Kirin goes "back in the day." Back to a time when I think (correct me if I'm wrong please,) that this was a "northeast China" restaurant. You know, northeast China, where the food is hot, spicy, garlicky, thick sauce, kinda  Koreanish.  (Think San Tung.) The name would indicate that, Kirin being tucked away in northeast China, right on the border with Siberian Russia, which it was a part of till Mao snatched it after the war. (Kirin's Russian Orthodox churches are still famous.) I think I remember eating here with a Korean friend many years ago, and I think I recall the food being red,hot, and spicy. At that time we thought Kirin was "the San Wang of the Richmond." So you can imagine my surprise when we entered and we heard all the waiters speaking Cantonese, and a quick look at the wall and window menus, showed us that this has been a Cantonese restaurant for a long time. Further, a quick look at the menu showed us that there were no "Koreanish" dishes here, (no Korean writing on the menu next to the descriptions, a giveaway. ) So oh well, no biggie, whatever. Cantonese food is one of our favs, so a quick mindset adjustment, (Winnie was looking forward to "Cham pon" (Korean-Chinese spicy seafood soup,) and we were good to go. So menu in hand, "what are we gonna eat now...." And then Winnie has a great idea. "Why don't we order stuff that we don't usually eat? " Wow! Profound. (Hey why didn't I think of that?) haha.  Expensive food here we come! We had a $60 gift certificate. So what if we go over and pay a bit extra, right? Haha. My lobster noodles, are suddenly "in da house." So we started to order, and the riches flowed; But first, let's establish a rating system. Move over Michelin, (bunch of stuffy ole white guys in starched shirts and tuxedos deciding what we should eat.) We need a "people's rating system," that reflects what real people with real pocketbooks eat. So the time has come for the "Sushi G Rating System." Designed for YOU not Elon Musk. "Power To The People," yelp style! So here goes. Yum-O! (with exclamation) means super good. "Yum-O" (no exclamation) means really good. Just "Yum" means good, and "bleh" means mediocre. Of course "gag" means awful. So now, that we are complete with the "sushi g rating system". (Wow, another yelp "trademark" for me! I'm unstoppable! I just keep pullin dem rabbits out of dem hats! One of the rare times I actually like myself! Haha,) First up, lobster noodles, (mandatory) Yum-O! Then. we had in random order, Deep fried tofu/ fish cake strips with bok choy. (Yum-o!) Chinese Greens with humongous button mushrooms, (Yum-o) Seafood Tofu Clay.Pot, (Yum-O) and Salt and Pepper Fried Squid, (Yum-o). After I asked, they gave us red bean dessert, (hong dao.) I had seen them bring out comp tapioca desserts (white, green,) to other tables after they finished their courses all nite, so after waiting and nothing came (but the bill,) I asked. And yes, they did bring it, but not willingly or happily, and with no comment or apology. We had just spent $75 there, wtf??? So one star off for kinda screwin up on the dessert at least, (and "profiling" at the most.) We were the only table that was not "all Chinese," and some had spent far less than us and got it automatically, but one look at us, and "not for them." They probably thought, "no need, they probably don't even know about this, or that they're supposed to get it." Sux. But that did not ruin my evening. As I sat there staring at bae, and then at my big a-- plate of expensive Lobster noodles, and as I thought "Tell the world that we finally got it all right, I choose you...." I felt like Jay-Z and Beyoncé.....until I got outside, and....no limo, ...just my old Ford Focus, (with a big a--'ticket on the windshield,) and then I realized, "nah, it's okay, I am, and always will be, just lil' ole sushi g,....,but this time, with a stomach full of Lobster Noodles.
author: George F.

description:
This place is flat out AMAZING. I mean some dishes are oily and could be a bit crispier, but the other stuff.. MUY BUENO!

I recommend the Chinese Chicken Salad. If you have a peanut allergy, ask for it without nuts. You could also try the lettuce cup, lobster noodle, fried squash, the friend salt and pepper chicken, etc. The tofu is great! Maybe try the seafood clay pot.
author: Jade F.

description: Great tomato beef chow mein with crispy noodles, which complimented well with the salt & pepper chicken wings.  Portions were large.  Ambiance was fair.  Prices were above average for this type of Chinese food.
author: Wally H.

description: Oh I still love the food here.  DELICIOUS cubed steak.  And it's not really cubed steak (what they call it on their menu).  Still, delicious tender slices of beef cooked with yummy gravy sauce and placed over some thinly sliced tomatoes...that's it, no veggie filler stuff cooked with it.  Their Mandarin pork chops are good too.  That is all for now...
author: Emy B.

description:
Kirin is so close to my apartment, so every now and then, I come here out of convenience. The dishes I've tried have all been pretty average. However, it looks like the more popular dishes (like the big rainbow raw fish salad) do have a loyal fan base. Too bad the portions for those are ginormous, and I've never had a chance to bring an army here to try them. 

If you do find yourself here, I would recommend the claypot dishes. Don't bother with their wonton soup.
author: Jing D.

description:
There are so many Chinese restaurants in this City that it's hard to tell what's good, and what isn't.  I divide them into a couple categories:

1. The truly awful ones that serve mostly Americanized-Chinese dishes. Food so bright and shiny you need to wear sunglasses. These have one billion items on their pink paper $5.95 lunch special menus, all Panda Express-y, minimal service, some good, all monster-sized portions, menu items that my Chinese mama has never heard of (what is egg foo young?), though it's still decent and a great value if you are hungryhippo-y.

2.  Chinese restaurants for the locals, with affordable, authentic, solid food.  The majority of the Chinese eateries you'll find in SF, food somewhat shiny, prices ranging from $7.95/entree and up, an endless variety of dishes that are authentic, often filled with crowds of multi-generational Chinese families fighting over checks. Money fight FTW.

3.  The nicer Chinese restaurants, the ones where you go for 10+ course banquet dinners, where they change your plate after every few courses, good service, VERY seafood heavy and an incredible value for the amount of food they give you, moist towelettes are often seen at these restaurants.  As are lobster-catching waiters who present to you live crustaceans for your inspection and approval. 

4. Expensive and clean Chinese restaurants that are Yelp- and/or city-guide-famous but that local Chinese don't go to.  I would imagine the food at these places is pretty good, but the lack of bang-for-your-buck deters most local Chinese people from frequenting. Value is a major criterion! Yank Sing is a prime example of this kind of restaurant. 

Kirin is a solid Type 2 restaurant.  Good pricing, tasty, somewhat shiny food, acceptable service, and pretty authentic.  I came here last Saturday, and we ordered the Golden Crispy Chicken (half a chicken = $10) that comes with the pink and orange shrimp chips that stick to your tongue, the salt and pepper squid, beef and snow peas, and winter melon soup.  The chicken was great, and the skin was fried lovely - you bite and hear the CRISP sound!  Beef and snow peas were blindingly shiny. Awesome. The salt and pepper squid was alright; I've had better ones at dim sum places, but this was still good.  The winter melon soup was so savory and very light - thank you, MSG!  

Everything was oh-so-solid, plus they gave us free dessert - either red bean soup or almond tofu, in addition to the standard fruit and fortune cookies.  Our entrees ranged in price from $7.50 to $9.75.  The service was fine too, though I think we were lucky to get one particularly nice waiter.  He offered us the free dessert and afterward another meaner waiter glanced over at our table and asked another colleague in Chinese: who decided to give them free dessert?!  Other waiter: who do you think?  

Hey waiters, heads up that a table of Chinese kids can understand you.  

But anyway, four very well-deserved stars for this solid Type 2 Chinese restaurant.  Meant to be eaten family-style, come here and enjoy some simple and good Chinese food. Though there wasn't any one dish that was so spectacular that I'd rave about it, everything was very good.  So if you're in the Outer Richmond, check it out.  Hopefully you get the nice waiter, too.
author: Vivian C.

description: Been a long time since I had been here. Still excellent. Kung pao chicken, broccoli beef, and my favorite dry braised green beans!!! We came to go to Zachary's pizza. But they were closed. It was like visiting an old friend. Oh yeah. The pan pacific own tins were amazing!!!
author: Mark P.

description:
I was just here a week ago for my bro's birthday celebration. The servers were very friendly (more so than regular Chinese restaurants) and attentive. The food, however, got worse (in my opinion).

Everything except the chicken salad was average. Most of the dishes were super salty (although we requested for low sodium) and drenched in sauce.

If you're looking for a superb Chinese restaurant, I suggest traveling half a dozen blocks down Geary and go to Hong Kong Lounge.
author: Jenny T.

description: Usually come here for large gatherings with my family. The staff here are friendly and the food is always good.
author: Sara L.

description:
This place is absolutely wonderful. Always top service and huge amounts of food! 
Order their:
-Chinese chicken salad (i love the cilantro and the pink ginger, it really gives it an unusual kick!)
-Lettuce cups (the filling is yummy and they always offer to give you more lettuce)
-Steak Cubes with big black mushrooms ( the sauce used for the beef is like no other and is really juicy and flavorful. i always order this everytime i go here)
-Lobster and/or Crab with garlic noodles (i think the salt and pepper King Crab is the best deep friend with garlic noodles. i've never had crab like that and am always sad when they're not in season :[ )
-Salt and Pepper Chicken Wings ( look no further for chinese chicken wings, kirins will have your mouth watering . these are the bomb).
author: Emerald I.

description:
The place was close by my work , so I would go semi often.
More than once we were treated a little rude, no biggie , the food was decent & the price pretty well.
 But yesterday , I ordered to go for myself & two other people. They took 20min. to get our order. The chubby faced guy, frowned & said something under his breath ,when we asked for hot sauce & soy sauce (most places just give it without asking)
 Here is the clincher; as I am finishing my meal I find a rather large earwig in my dish
How do you post a pic on this thing ? of couse I took one.
author: Marcus M.

description:
I've never had it before, and was skeptical, but my grandparents knew what they were talking about when they put a piece of the chicken stuffed with sticky rice on my plate. The crispy chicken skin was greasy but so good when you bite through it and into the soft, chewy, sticky rice. The differing textures caught my attention and I realized how delicious it was! I LOVE IT! Chicken sticky rice - you are now on my list of favorite Chinese dishes. I'll have to go to other restaurants and try it.

We ordered an extremely large amount of food for take out including all the usual dishes: pork spare ribs, mushrooms and bok choy, roast duck, catfish, lettuce cups, shrimp and walnuts, a squash and mushroom soup, and their chinese chicken salad amongst many other dishes that escape my mind. My particular piece of duck wasn't cooked thoroughly and looked a bit bloody near the bone. I found the food ordinary and only found the stuffed chicken worthy of remembering.
author: Samantha L.

description:
Call me a dissenter, but we didn't love it. It was quite pricey. The kung pao prawns were spicy, though the menu did not prepare us for it. The walnut scallops were yummy, as everything fried is. I'd take Hunan Cafe #2 any day!
Update: the kung pao shrimp was much more yummy the next day.
author: Andrew K.

description: This restaurant is a hidden gem. I was impressed with the service and the high quality of the meals! It was certainly the best Chinese food I have had in a while. I would highly recommend to anyone on this side of the city.
author: Dana M.

description:
We used to come here all of the time when we lived 2 blocks away. 

It used to be owned by this family and then they changed management to the chef that used to cook at 8 immortals? My grandma used to frequent that place all of the time and that's how we knew. 

From here, we used to always get one of the set menu dealios and it was pretty tasty. 

Pretty good Chinese food, but it can get a little pricy. Best for  large groups or fancy get-togethers. You know, special occasion sorta-deals.
author: Alison N.

description:
After a so-so Father's Day banquet, I couldn't help but remember my parents' disappointment about the Stuffed Chicken with Sweet Rice (aka Loh Mai Gai - a traditional dish that, like Peking Duck, most restaurants require a day's notice to prepare, except for here). I immediately thought of this place, recalling that they've never eaten here. When going to restaurants, customers are best advised to order their signature dishes. We tried two of the three as our menu consisted of the following: 

Appetizer 
Rainbow Chicken Salad (signature) - No, this is not the same that you find in most Chinese restaurants and it's definitely not the same as the Costco kit. A mixture of rice noodles, fried shredded wonton skin, marinated/pickled ginger, peanuts, and, of course, shredded chicken meat. The other signature dish that we did NOT order (parents squeamish about raw fish) is their Rainbow Raw Fish Salad as it would have been repetitious. - $18.00 (small - enough to feed a party of six) 
Soup 
Dried Bok Choy Soup (Choy Gon Tong) - A clean tasting broth with featuring sun-dried bok choy, almond seeds, and pork meat. The trick to this soup is cleaning the bok choy well, which they certainly did. - complimentary 
Entrees 
Sugar Pea Sprouts with Dried Scallop - Sauteed large pea sprouts in a thick sauce filled with shredded dried scallop. This dish was a good pairing with our other entree. Everything was perfectly cooked and seasoned. - $15.75 
Stuffed Chicken with Sweet Rice (signature) - Deep fried chicken skin encases a tasty sticky rice seasoned with preserved pork (lap yuk - think cured ham), diced shitake mushrooms, pork meat, and dried shrimp. The trick is keeping the skin crispy and cooking the rice correctly (not too dry nor mushy). Success. - $33.00 
Dessert 
Almond Jello with fruit cocktail - This was only okay for me as I like a heavy almond flavor to the jello which was lacking. 
Taro Tapioca - Hot sweet soup option that my parents chose. They finished it so it must have passed their test. - both complimentary, so how can you complain. 

We arrived before 6 pm on a Saturday evening, which seemed like the right time as I found a parking space about a block away (parking can be difficult as this is the Richmond District). The dining room had only three occupied tables when we arrived, but it was mostly filled by the time we left around 7:15 pm. There are more large tables here as it is obviously a banquet destination for many locals. I noticed Jason G's lunch and Steve L's banquet experiences are great references for dining here with friends and family respectively.  As we left the restaurant, my parents kept trying to compare the meal to other places from past dinners. But I think we were in agreement that what they do well here is very good.
author: Mike C.
