description: This is my 4th time to your restaurant. Why do I give it 1 star after being here several times and even taking pics and promoting your place? Because this time, my chow mien came with a cockroach. Ahhhh... why are you doing this to me! I love your food but not enough to come back after finding a roach.
author: KL H.

description:
There are a couple of winners.  They include the rainbow fish salad and the sticky rice chicken.

The rainbow fish salad contains raw filet fish, but when tossed with the other ingredients, you barely can tell.  This dish reminds me of my childhood and of my dad.

Kirin makes a memorable sticky rice chicken.  This dish has to be ordered in advance.  This dish alone will fill you up.  It's a whole chicken butterflied and stuffed with sticky rice and other ingredients.  The chicken skin is crisp, and the rice is mixed with the right combination of dried shrimp, chopped mushrooms, and meat.

The big minus is the difficulty in finding a parking space.  Come and eat early or suffer the consequences.  There is a paid parking lot on 24th & Geary where Patelco C.U. used to stand, so that is an option.
author: Shirley N.

description:
I came here for the first time this past weekend. My husband's extended family loves coming here and now I know why! The food here is soo good and such great quality! I definitely want to come back here for the same foods we had and some new ones like this chinese chicken salad or the rainbow raw fish salad, mhmm both sound yummy and huge! 

We had the Peking Duck with buns, Crispy Chicken Stuffed with Rice, Winter Melon Soup, Steamed Fish, Stir-Fry Vegetables with Scallops and Broccoli with Beef. I'm sure there was more that I can't remember but all of it was soo soo good. Especially the Peking Duck with buns and the Crispy Chicken Stuffed with Rice. Also the Winter Melon soup was sooo delicious! but that tasted more chicken/pork soup and some winter melon with it since it was super flavourful, either way it was all super delicious. 

I would definitely come back here, too bad it's sooo far for us and parking totally sucks. We had to pay metered parking. $2 for 1 hour and we were there for like 3 hours... blah. Only because we had a big communion celebration luncheon going on, so it was worth it for the parking.
author: Grace L.

description:
Great spot in the Richmond.  Everything I've ordered has been good - it's a clean, comfortable place with good service.
They have one of my absolute favorite dishes: Prawns and scrambled eggs over chow fun (not rice) - delicious!!
author: Brian C.

description:
We originally wanted to dine at Hong Kong Lounge but since there was a wedding, the restaurant was closed to the public. After walking several blocks to Mayflower and discovering that the wait time was 30 minutes, we were starving and decided to try Kirin. Bad mistake.

The moment you walk into the restaurant, you can immediately tell that it's not as popular as other chinese restaurants down the street. There were few chinese people, signifying that it's not authentic enough. The entrees were pretty much average for a chinese restaurant - nothing special. We did have Cantonese style lobster (over noodles) and that was pretty decent, but is nothing compared to HK Lounge or Mayflower.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Service: Grade B+... the server was polite and kind.  They weren't very social

Food: Grade B-... we ordered a few dishes..  The dry fried ribs were tasty and everything else was average.

Overall, OK  to TRY!!
author: E T.

description:
The price/food quality ratio is very high here. Huge selection of great food...from very ethnic to very basic good Chinese food. I love their chow mein, their rice dishes,...great vegetable dishes. 

The portions are very good. The staff is nice. It is a pretty clean place too. I like the quality of tong kiang better...but the price is so expensive there and the quantity is so small that KIRIN wins hands down!
author: David G.

description:
Where do i begin. I'll start with the waiter. He comes over to take our order. Barks at us then Burps literally in my friends face then hurries us along. the entire time he's taking our order he's not paying attention to anything we're saying because he's talking to other employees and customers, then asks us twice sometimes 3 times what it was we just ordered. All the while he's making these crude snorting sounds. Disgusting! after out food came out i was pleased. Until i saw a little beedy eyed friend running across my TABLE! YES! a ROACH was on my table. and if you want to see it for yourself you can.

 http://www.facebook.com/video/video.php?v=1791013107761

The most disgusting place i've ever been. This restaurant needs to be shut down until it's had a full health inspection.
author: Reuben B.

description:
It's one thing to go out and "grab a drink" with your nearest and dearest...it's quite another to know you are about to consume large quantities of tropical libations with your fellow safariers.  

Thankfully, I had some sense that the night could go downhill quickly on an empty stomach, so our fearless leader and I came here to get takeout.  Standard fare that you would expect, I went with the lemon chicken to go along with the tropical theme, and white rice against my better judgement.  I have been telling myself to eat more brown rice, but that goes right out the window when I'm hungry.

The food came out quickly, and although we really wanted to eat it out of cartons with chopsticks like you see them do in the movies, I could just see how bad it would have gone with chopsticks and a large bowl full of booze.  And the swordfights that would have ensued with said chopsticks.

My lemon chicken was mediocre at best, but it got the job done.  It's a cute little place, though, and I wouldn't mind going back in the future and trying another dish.  Although I could definitely see another Trad'r Sams trip immediately afterwards.
author: Pam S.

description:
Just look in the window.  95% of the patrons are Chinese in this Chinese restaurant.  So there you go.

Typical menu, but with some specials that shouldn't be missed.  Best part is, most of these are usually special order in other restaurants, but Kirin has these available year round.

Just a couple of my favorites:

Chicken stuffed with sticky rice
Snake soup (OK, this one is a winter special)

Other favorites include:

Fried fish - I think these are bait fish?  Fabulously salt and pepper fried with jalapenos.
Walnut prawns
Fantastic chicken salad
Roast squab

Yummy, yummy, yummy for my tummy!
author: Denise M.

description:
Sadly we came here for my mom's birthday because I heard it was good...well, it wasn't. Everything was horrible! I can't believe it's because I ordered the wrong thing because it all tasted like shit!!!

Sugar Peas Sprout with garlic sauce      13.50  3 stars  the best thing all night but look how much they charge for some fucking pea sprouts, really?
Salt & Pepper Squid *      10.50  2 stars  ok but nothing special  
Golden Crispy Chicken    half 11.00  whole 22.00  1 star  this was overcooked and dryer than the mojave desert and had no flavor
Peking Duck order in advance      30.00  1 star  the duck was old, greasy, and gross
Shredded Chicken Chow Mein       6.95  1 star  thank God there was hot sauce and white pepper at the table
Mandarin Spareribs       10.75  I ordered it but they forgot to cook it, lucky us

I would not go back if they paid me to, it was that bad. How they get any ratings beyond 1 star is beyond me. Then again, my father was a chef & I ran 2 Chinese restaurants.
author: May G.

description:
1. Food didn't have much flavor.
2. I don't think the waiter gave me the entire quantity of my leftovers.
3. Fast service.
4. Average ambience.

Bottom Line: I won't go back and I do not recommend this restaurant.
author: John W.

description:
It's ok.

Once you eat Chinese food in Hawaii, nothing will compare.

They ran out of chow fun so we ate the chow mein, which was really mushroom-y, lemon chicken, which was dry and beef broccoli which was okay, not enough sauce.  

Tea was good and so was the service.

But, I think I'll wait till I go to Hawaii to eat Chinese food.
author: Marisa R.

description: We love Kirins , favorites would include calamari, fried chicken wings,chicken salad noodles & hong to Yee won ton
author: Tommy W.

description:
Is it me...or do waiters at Chinese restaurants dislike Filipino patrons?

I took my wife's family here for lunch on Labor Day as they were visiting for the day; touring the beautiful City by the Bay on an absolutely gorgeous day. The man who greeted us asked us how many were in our group and rudely showed a corner table with an abrupt "Here!" with a tone of disgust. For a party of eight, we were missing a couple of plates and teacups but nothing was offered. We had to grab them from the next table. 

He returns with the menus and dumps them on our table. He won't even bother to say what the lunch special was and abruptly leaves. We check out the Lunch Menu and was pleasantly surprised to see that the majority of the dish where under $8.00. They ranged from $5.50 to $12.00. All agreed that it was a bargain indeed. We ordered some Rice Plates and Noodles, with a couple of Beef Won Ton soup for all. 

After several minutes, he returns with the soup and starts pouring them in those tiny soup bowls with a ladle. But he's splashing the soup and some are spilled onto the table. I look at his face and they are stone cold. Not even an acknowledgment as he leaves us yet again when he has done his duties. He didn't even bother to wipe the table from the soup spill he created. Nor did he bother to serve the soup and left them as is without saying a word. He's lucky we were hungry, otherwise, I would have dumped the soup on top of his head. I look at my wife, I look at her cousin and we laughed at the absurdity of the service. It's this kind of service that perpetuates the typical rude waiter stereotypes at Chinese restaurants. 

Then we received our lunch order and didn't expect a pile of food on a big plate. Boy they were hefty, and they surely didn't skimp on ingredients. You also wouldn't know there was a world-wide rice shortage by the amounts they were serving. Plus, their food was actually good. The seafood was full of seafood just as advertised. You usually get a good dose of vegetables with your seafood when you order them at other restaurants...but not this one.

I had almost forgotten about the bad service we had gotten, and the food almost made up for the experience until I noticed the same waiter serving a group of other patrons. Now this group had arrived at least half an hour after us and the service they received compared to ours was like night and day. He was carefully serving their soup and even placed each bowl in front of every patron. He even managed to crack a smile and speak with them.

Then this got me thinking:

- Do we look like we don't tip?
- Is it a cultural thing?
- Or is it because I am not your kind?

I know I am implying a racial undertone here but this is what we experienced and witnessed first hand. It's kinda too bad since we did enjoy their food. I'll give them 2 1/2 stars for now and will give them another chance to improve on our return visit. I would rate their food a 4 but the poor service greatly downgraded their rating. I'll give them another chance and only because the food and tea were really good. 

To be continued?
author: John G.

description:
We tend to stick to our usual Chinese eateries but every so often my mom like go out and have dinner out of the blue at a new place. You have to think quick on your feet, you pull our your cell phone and fire up the Yelp App which this time, pointed us to Kirin Chinese Restaurant.

Upon walking in you feel like this is a C- Chinese restaurant. 

This is how I grade my Chinese Restaurants:
A - Think Gary Danko served Chinese food, eloquent, amazing food, and exceptional service.
B - Think Koi's Palace, not the best, but trying to be Tommy Toy's status (deep down it is just a C grade Chinese Restaurant that cheated on the test) Oh, and they charge an arm and a leg for food and service that is not warranted.
C - A C restaurant serves decent Chinese food, big portions, decent pricing, still loud, but has a semi-clean bathroom but it still smells nasty.
D - A HOLE in the WALL, you see swarms of flies buzzing, dirty, grungy, loud.

There are no F's given because your Chinese mother would not approve and give you a good whacking with the bird feather duster.

Parking was a bit difficult during dinner time so we ended up parking a couple blocks away near Presidio Middle School. We were greeted by an elderly hostess who wasn't too friendly but just pointed at a table in the back near the kitchen and threw down the menus. (I hate sitting next to the kitchen where I can watch people prepare my food. I don't mind it at Pluto's because they know you can see them so no funny business.)

We ordered a bunch of food off their dated sticky menus and waited patiently for our food. The food soon came and everything was soooooo SHINY! like it was gleaming!!! You need sunglasses to eat this food. SHINY = OILY! Everything I ate left an oil slick down my esophagus and no water in the brown frosted plastic cups can flush it down. 

Overall my experience at Kirin was not the best but you can see that this restaurant targets the local crowd who are just lazy to cook at home that night. The prices are reasonable for the amount of food but I would have second thoughts coming back to this place.
author: Myron J.

description: This is my go to spot for Chinese food not because it is awesome, I mean I had better but because this place is near my work. I always order their beef and egg chowfun or pineapple chicken fried rice. Their prices are reasonable, and food is good. I have never eaten there, I only call them for takeouts.
author: Lubin T.

description:
I love this place its great, staff is friendly and everything taste so yummy in the tummy, its not too expensive but well worth the adventure out to the outer Richmond :) I go all the time with my friends. 
I recommend the clay pot or any of the sea food dishes they are  all amazing
author: Veronica V.

description: Nothing special, but maybe we came on an off night. They were fast to serve us but the food was not that good. I saw many other tables order similar dishes (we ordered from a set menu) and maybe the cook rushed to create large quantities. Would be hesitant to come back.
author: Kelly S.

description:
Yelp never steers me wrong! Due to the ridiculous dearth of Chinese restaurants in Marin County, we have to venture to SF.  Kirin's location is very conveninent to the Golden Gate Bridge.

I went with my husband, sister and 2 kids.  We had won ton soup, the pea shoots with garlic sauce, 1/2 crispy fried chicken, walnut prawns, eggplant with pork, salt and pepper fish, and the house crispy fried noodles.  Everything was DELICIOUS and served piping hot.  I wanted to get the rice stuffed chicken, but at $33, I had to pass!   My son LOVED the salt and pepper fish - and he generally dislikes Chinese food! 

I'd probably give 5 stars but the service was fairly atrocious.  We had to wait FOREVER to order (the restaurant was empty), our food took a long time, we had to ask multiple times for our first glass of water, we had to ask multiple times for forks (for the kids) and for a second glass of water (my son thought the salt/pepper fish was a little spicy).  We then waited forever for the check.... my expectation for service in a Chinese restaurant is generally pretty darn low but this was pretty dismal. 

Anyhow - great food, service not significantly worse than any other Chinese restaurant in SF - we'd definitely go back!
author: Jen K.

description:
Great place in the Richmond District to eat at. 

Get the salad. Chicken or sashimi. But, make sure you order it early. You can't go wrong with the chicken wings either. Crunchy, a bit a tang from the jalepeno peppers. If you know you are going to eat there, call ahead the day before and order the stuffed whole chicken. It's sweet/sticky rice stuffed inside a whole chicken and deep fried. Just get it, trust me.

Our family eats here alot actually and it turns out to be a benefit. The staff and owners remember us and sometimes give us a complimentary dish or something the chef will cook up special that's not on the menu.

Street parking only and it can be challenging to find. Worth the circling around the blocks though.
author: Brian L.

description:
My in-laws get take out from here, A LOT.  They also eat here for family dinners, A LOT.  I am talking a few times a week on a regular basis.  You would think they would get tired of their food, but actually it's good Chinese food so we keep going back.  

I recommend the chicken salad over lo mein noodles.  I know, salad at a Chinese restaurant?  This one is good.  You get some greens from the lettuce, protein from the chicken and starch from the noodles.  A perfect meal in one dish.

Other dishes on repeat:  ma po tofu (it's spicy and good ratio of meat to tofu), peking spare ribs/gingo pai got, the chicken wings, and the minced pork with long beans.  If you like chow fun, go during lunch because by dinner time they usually run out. They also make a good honey walnut prawn.  I am one of the few in my family who likes to eat bitter melon.  They make a good bitter melon with chicken or beef.

If you are looking for a vegetable dish, try the...it's sounds like dao miu in Chinese, I don't know what it is in English.  Ask for it with spicy peppers, it adds a kick to the greens.  

I could seriously review most of the dishes on the menu.  This is a solid consistent Chinese restaurant in the Richmond District.  It might be more pricey than the Chinese take out place on your street, but it's worth it.
author: Rowena B.

description:
staff is very customer oriented! super friendly, fast service, and easy going. They always get my order right and never charge me extra if I ask for extra plates. My togo order is always done on time and I never have to wait. the portion is pretty decent for the price you pay. I havent tried anything special here, just the typical pineapple chicken friend rice and chow fun which was decent. 

- 1 star, do not order the general chows chicken, deep fried, oily, all batter, and very little pieces of chicken.
author: Quyen T.

description: Fried Chicken Wings are tasty. Hong Kong Style Chow Mein is good too.
author: Brian L.

description:
A long time family favorite clearly disappointed us.  Far from their usual standards of very good food and friendly service, we were disappointed on Thanksgiving day.  As in past years, we arranged for the family (2 tables) to have dinner.  We had pre ordered the winter melon soup.

Upon our arrival, the restaurant was quiet with few diners.  I slowly ordered food for the two tables I went it over it twice to make sure no confusion.  Due to the dietary likes and dislikes of the attendees, the dishes were different for the two tables.  
Why would the waiter be irritated with this arrangement - I don't understand.

Food.  The food was just okay.  Winter melon soup lacked some of the ingredients that we had treasured for many years.  The soup was below par.  Chicken stuffed with sweet rice was equally bland.  Rainbow raw fish salad - wish we could say but it never came.  Shrimp with snow peas - good only if you could find the shrimp - no more than 4 pieces.  So and so on.  Very subpar performance on a night when business was very light.

Aside from the missing rainbow raw fish salad and the indifference of the waiter, the staff did mixed up the distinct orders for the two tables.  We had to continuously swap dishes to ensure the correct.
author: Bill L.

description: The only thing you need to know about this place is that you have to have to have to always order the RAW FISH SALAD.  According to my father, they don't make it anywhere else in the city, and it's a traditional dish from the village in China that my parents are from.  It's raw fish, spices, crispy won ton chips, and a ton of other things.  I love it so much I order it for take out even though it can be pricy.........(I think a small salad that serves 2 is about $30).............It is worth the cost though as it's amazing and you can't get it anywhere else.
author: Denise B.

description:
We were back here again, for an extended family get together/Chinese New Year lunch with my father-in-law's side of the family. We had the same banquet menu from my last review, so I have nothing new to add as far as any new dishes. (See previous review for details of the dishes) 

I've been here many times since my last review, and will say this, the dishes and their preparations have been consistently good, and the servers were attentive and friendly, as always. Not surprising, since most of the staff, including the chef/owner, has worked together for more than 20 years. 

Good thing we planned this banquet at lunch, as we were pretty full after wards. 

Still remains a family favorite, and I'm sure we'll be back here again.
author: Steve L.

description: Wow! Very VERY tasty food here. I love taking new people here to see them leave happy with a full tummy. Try it. You will LOVE it. Having some tonight !!!!
author: C U.

description:
Where's the meat?!

I had just finished working out after a long day at the office, so I was feeling especially tired and hungry (i.e. grumpy). My husband and I ordered a large bowl of winter melon soup and the stuffed chicken with sweet rice. A whole chicken should be enough for us, right? WRONG.

The soup wasn't particularly good - it didn't taste fresh, almost as if it had been made a week ago. The broth was a bit too salty and didn't have the lovely winter melon flavor incorporated into it. We then had to wait what seemed like half an hour for the chicken to come out...

The dish is basically the skin of a whole chicken that has been fried and stuffed with sticky rice...that's it. Initially, we enjoyed the combination of the crispy fried chicken skin with the warm sticky rice (not sweet rice as it's named). Then after about two pieces, we started to wonder about the chicken meat. There wasn't any chicken in the rice - were they going to bring the meat out separately (like they do with Peking duck)? Nope. You never get the chicken meat! How can they charge $30 for a chicken and not give you any of the meat?! It's absurd. I needed protein...just skin and rice did not to cut it for me. They also skimped on the amount of Chinese sausage in the sticky rice - just a few tiny bits instead of whole slices. No meat, bland, and greasy...never again. Such an unsatisfying meal.

[Note: I probably wouldn't have been as disgruntled about the stuffed chicken had it been one of several dishes instead of my main course, but I still think it's a crime to charge $30 for under-seasoned chicken skin and rice.]
author: Karin V.

description:
When i lived in the city, this was our go- to chinese restaurant.  
Great, authentic chinese food. Very friendly staff.  I think the same staff has 
been here a while.  Great for groups.  
Food is very good. B+
Service is very good A-
Parking is tough 
The bathrooms could be a little better maintained
author: uscot S.

description:
This place is good for take-out as the portions are huge! 

I just got BBQ pork chow mein and shrimp won ton soup for $12. It could easily feed 2 people. The lunch menu is really cheap.

The food is nothing spectacular but for the quantity and price, I like it.
author: Rachel G.

description: The best lobster noodles in town!  $19.99 and you get a medium size lobster and noodles!  We had their salt and pepper crabs and salt and pepper prawns.  Their food is very good.
author: S C.

description:
I've been to Kirin a few times and was in love with the food the first few times when we ordered dishes a la carte off the menu.  Today, we decided to try one of their set dinners (the one for $248) and I thought the food was very meh.  Although the presentation of the melon soup (supposedly $40 alone) was very dramatic (they cooked the soup in the melon and then carved it down after they served a bowl to everyone), it only tasted okay.  The sticky rice stuffed chicken dish was the worst that I've ever had.  The skin was hard and chewy and the sticky rice was very bland.  The Peking duck looked very unappetizing so I didn't even bother to try it (they didn't even cut the skin off correctly and where was the cucumber and scallions that it's supposed to be served with?).  The only decent dishes tonight were the honey walnut prawns and the steamed fish.

I usually love Kirin but I was pretty disappointed with their food today =(  I guess we'll stick to ordering a la carte next time.  I absolutely love their salt and pepper frog legs (and I don't usually even even frog legs!) and their duck egg and clam dish (not sure what it's called in English but it's basically like salt and pepper clams with the shells on and it has bits of preserved salted duck eggs in it) and the Rainbow Raw Fish Salad (basically small pieces of sashimi fish with fried wonton skins, crispy noodles, preserved ginger)...delish!
author: Katelynn L.

description:
Cant go wrong eating our state bird - and I give many thanks for his small bodied sacrifice!  If you roll through the Richmond district in the Yay I suggest eating the Quail, the raw fish salad, and the salted fried pork - makes you wanna say "Daaaammmmnnnnn son"  and it ain't even in Ctown (which honestly don't eat in Ctown - go where the locals go!)

I love it long tine.
author: Fourty F.

description: Yummy food. Very courteous service. Will be a regular stop when I make my biweekly visits to this neighborhood.
author: Cynthia L.

description:
Hit and miss:
Wintermelon soup: ok, unfortunately it has msg and can't be ordered w/o.
Stuffed chicken w/ sticky rice: good; could be tastier w/ a few more ingredients.
Lobster noodles: noodles were tasty; lobster a bit goopy, needs more roasted flavor.
Peking duck: not that meaty or moist, buns were TERRIBLE, tasted like they were frozen and over-microwaved to the point that they were dry and dense with tough edges.  we all know what  overnuked bread tastes like. ugh.
author: Pat W.

description:
-yet another Sterling Birthday Dinner tonight!

spectacular Rainbow fish salad

West Lake Beef Soup

Honey walnut prawns
Glutinous rice chicken
Chinese broccoli in oyster sauce
Peking red ribs sweet & sour
Steamed stuffed tofu
Fried sliced eggplant
Longlife noodles
choice of sweetened red bean or almond gel cubes with fruit cocktail

and our Strawberry pavé layer cake.  (got coffee?)
author: Clifford L.

description:
Went there after a recommendation.  Totally satisfied.  I've eaten at many chinese restaurants in SF and Kirin rates very highly.  Ordered from the chef's specialties and was not disappointed.

Service was pretty good, plenty of waiters ready to help. 

I'll be going back there on a regular basis to try some of their other dishes.
author: Acura Nsx T.

description:
This place is pretty good. We went on a Wednesday night and it wasn't busy at all. Our meal was a little pricey but I think it's beause we ordered a few specialty dishes.

We ordered the Rainbow Raw Fish Salad which is unique - quite tasty. The Conch (sliced) and Steamed Soft Bean Cake were pretty good. They served us a soup - I only know the Chinese name but it was very flavorful.

We also ordered the Stuffed Chicken. This was the second time (R and G Lounge) I've had this kind of dish and I think aside from how cool it sounds to stuff and reshape a chicken with rice and skin, it's a bit too bland for my liking. Not dinging the place - just not my kind of dish. I've included a picture of how it looks. It's kinda neat. If you've never tried it, it's worth a try.
author: Barney M.

description:
I wanted a Chinese restaurant that was authentic and different from the standard fare.  From the live seafood tanks to the chef's menu full of dishes I had never heard of, this was just the place I had mind.  Also, the friendly waiters and laughing, talking families all around made for a great atmoshpere.

There were two of us and two kids, so we went ahead and got the special with the chicken salad and winter melon soup with four entrees.  Of course it was way too much, but the salad and soup are Kirin specialties and I wanted to try some new dishes. 

The soup and chicken salad definately lived up to their reputations.  All the entrees were great as well but the standout for me was the pork and oyster clay pot.  It actually had the largest oysters I've ever seen in it, and the whole thing was just the definition of savory.  Great experience!
author: Mark W.

description:
We decided to try a new chinese restaurant while in the richmond area and this one popped up on yelp as a frontrunner. First impression, it's relatively clean and wide open, doesn't feel cramped at all. Second impression, the host guy was not very friendly. Just grunted and pointed at a table for us to sit out. 

The three of us weren't very hungry and just wanted a snack so we ordered two dishes among the three of us: 1.) spicy salted chicken and 2.) conch with mixed veggies and yellow chives.  It ended up being a lot of food because the portions were pretty large and they give you free house soup and free house dessert (tapioca or almond jello).

The food was pretty good. The chicken wings were ginormous and very tasty. The conch dish was pretty generous too. A lot of places give you little conch and add in tons of cheap veggies like celery and carrots. This one had a lot of conch and yellow chives and formosa mushrooms.

Overall, the food was above average. I knocked it down a star from a 4 because of the grumpy man in the front.
author: Theresa N.

description: Good traditional dishes. I personally like the Rainbow salad. It can get a bit crowded during the busy times and getting in and out of your seat is hard because all the tables are stacked next to each other.
author: Beth A.

description: My bf and I ate here a couple months ago and we were extremely disappointed. The wait staff barely paid attention to us and were rather rude. We ordered sweet and sour chicken, Mongolian beef, and steamed rice. Our food took forever to come out and it wasn't all that great. I felt it was a little pricey as well. We're never going back again!
author: Fallon P.

description:
Excellent food & service.  My family's favorite go to place for good Chinese food, and special family gatherings.

THEIR UNIQUE MUST HAVES - 
Fish Salad
Lettuce Cups
Chicken Sticky Rice
There's so many other great dishes here - you can't go wrong with anything.
author: Meredith K.

description:
I really love the fried chicken here! If you order nothing else, do order the fried chicken. You cannot leave without eating it! The chicken salad was also very good. No, it is not your typical salad, but it is freakin good. The pan fried noodles were also pretty tasty. The service was very attentive and even gave us calamari on the house. 

Eat it. Love the Fried Chicken. Repeat.
author: Jenna s.

description:
Always the place to visit for Chinese food in the Outer Richmond! Bang for your buck.

Recommendations:
Fried Chicken Wings
Wonton in soup base
Combination Hong Kong Style Pan Fried Noodles
Beef Chow Fun
author: Carol P.

description:
Tried the Hong Tao Yee Won Ton for lunch.  Always on the lookout for a good HTYWT place in the Bay Area.  The soup looked good.  I like the use of real crab in the broth, and the cilantro was a nice touch.  The won ton dumplings were bland and tasteless.  

The bathroom also smelled, but I guess that's normal for Chinese (non-fusion) food in the City.
author: Jason And Monica L.

description: my favorite neighborhood chinese restaurant! the waiters are always really nice and provide quick service. the food is also very consistent and always leaves me more than satisfied.
author: Sabrina L.

description: I've been going here for years because my uncle had his pharmacy next door.  The food has always been flavorful and they make the best traditional san francisco cantonese food.  The roast duck yee wonton is fantastic and everything i want (shredded roast duck, fried wonton, canned mushrooms and peas in soup).  Savory, flavorful and gives me memories of my childhood.  I also ordered the curry tomato beef pan fried noodles, perfect!!  A lot of places don't make this correctly b/c they're just cantonese restaurants and i think this is also an SF chinatown kind of dish.  The key is to make the tomato beef first and then add the curry.  I ordered to go and they separated my noodles to keep them crispy.  Sweet, curry, savory with a bit of a kick.  When i've been for dinner the fish salad and pressed chicken with sticky rice is a favorite.  Kirin you never let me down.
author: Susan Z.

description:
3.25

Went here for a family event.  All of the dishes were decent, but for some reason they weren't all that flavored to me.  Portion sizes are averaged sized, service was ok, and parking was decent (on the street Sunday).  Couldn't comment on the price because this family event was prepaid for...
author: Brian Y.

description:
My family always comes here for Chinese New Year.  I also had both of my daughters' coming out parties here.  The staff is great and always remembers my family.  They're friendly and helpful.  The food is yummy!  The way the melon is cut for the soup is decorative.  Every time I eat here I always have my favorite dishes as I love Kirin's raw fish salad, black bean clams, honey mayonnaise walnut shrimp, and steamed fish.  
The parking is atrocious in this neighborhood though so if you have reservations, come earlier for sure to find parking.
author: Kekumukula N.

description:
Always consistently great food and service!  No complaints at all about Kirin.  My family and I have been coming here for years and years.  I'm not sure what it is about this place, but it seems to be the central hub for Americanized Chinese families seeking a great meal.  While my family is extremely Americanized, Kirin never disappoints on the authenticity of the food.  Definitely one of the best Chinese restaurants in San Francisco.  

Overall, environment is very clean for a Chinese restaurant.  There are about 8-10 round tables for big parties. and the rest are 4 tops.  

Food is top notch here.  
-  Winter Melon Soup, the melon is carved whole, and the soup is poured into it.  Very flavorful. Great on a cold day. 
- Cubed Steak with Veggies:   The beef is very tender and the sauce makes the meat extra juicy.  
- Salt and Pepper Chicken Wings: *Licks lip*  Chicken is very meaty, fried to the perfect crisp-ness, and seasonsed perfectly with salt, pepper and garlic.  Definitely a FAVORITE of mine. 
-  Chicken Stuffed with Sticky Rice:  Can't talk about Kirin without talking about the whole chicken.  A meal all within itself.  The sticky rice is so yummy with Chinese sausage, cabbage, mushrooms, and I believe peanuts?  Love the thin layer of crispy skin on top.  Definitely for-go white rice when ordering this dish. 

Service here is the best.  All of the servers are very attentive, accomodating, and friendly.  This is the best place to come for big family gatherings and holidays.  Customer service at Chinese restaurants is always a hit or miss, more often a MISS for me,  but here at Kirin, it's always a HIT.
author: Cass J.

description: This should be ZERO stars. Found parts of a plastic bag in a spring roll.  I can not recommend eating at or from this restaurant! Yelp recommends not to share photos of personal experiences on the public site, so a picture can be seen on my personal account.
author: ben b.

description:
I came here wanting to try the rainbow chicken salad.  Since it was only my boyfriend and I  eating, it would've been ridiculous for us to order the salad because it was $18 for a HUGE plate!!  I plan to come back with a group to try it for sure.
We ended up ordering the Fried Flounder and the Chicken with Black Mushrooms and Soft Bean Cake.  Both dishes were kind of tasteless.  I was expecting it to be more flavorful!  Even the complimentary House Soup had more flavor in it!  Hopefully my next experience will be a tastier one.
author: jesiree b.

description: The food is decent and price is in the range of $6+. The service is good, but when it's busy, good luck. It is clean for a Chinese restaurant as the plates and chopsticks were alright to use. I only go here for lunch and haven't had much to complain about. The portion is good sized and a bit more compared to other restaurants around. Parking maybe a bit of a problem as you need to find a space a few blocks away. Would recommend if your in the Richmond area, looking for good portion Chinese food.
author: Scott Y.

description:
OH HECK NO, don't come here if you don't want to get pissed off! We ordered ' (salted egg yolk crab)' that tasted nothing like it. There was no egg yolk crab flavor, instead there was some kind of stinky smell. It's some kind of stinky fish smell (preserved fish paste?). YUCK, the more I eat the that dish, the more upset my stomach felt.

Horrible customer service, especially coming from the FAT waiter. We came here a few times and for some reason, he's always the one to serve us. Boy, he has some serious attitude problem. When we addressed the problem with the 'salted egg yolk crab dish,' he was no help at all. He told us he's sure that is what we ordered. Then, why is it that other customer's 'salted egg yolk crab dish' has a different color and texture from that of ours? 

Other dishes were pretty good but I refuse to give them even 3 stars because the crab dish made me feel sick and they have poor customer service. Oh and there was something in my glass of water. Can you say DD (DISTURBINGLY DISGUSTING)? YUCK.
author: Forest T.

description: How can one restaurant get such a variety of stars?  Easy.  It depends on who you are.  The five stars are going to come from the second/third generation SF Chinatown customers who know someone who knows someone else, and relatives.  And they are going to get the food, service and respect.  The others are out of luck.  When I or my family comes here, we always see someone ( relative, friend, friend's relative, etc.  I am related to Gary C., his review was 2 weeks ago ) We talk and catch up which always brings a waiter over and he is introduced, and then it goes.  The best is when my mother-in-law does the reservations and ordering.  Never had a bad meal here.
author: Michael N.

description: Came here once a few years ago with a coworker. I really didn't see anything special about this place other than the price being $$ and it being surrounded by parking meters so made lunch difficult in paying for parking.
author: M C.

description:
We were sitting down for dinner when I heard a buzzing sound...I turned around and saw Mr Manager/ Owner SHAVING!  Yes- SHAVING his beard/ mustache at the cash register- in the dining room!  REAL CLASSY guy there!  Nothing tasted right after that...

Most of the food here is comparable to Lucky Fortune down the street, but the prices are a lot higher.  The Lamb Stew was tough to chew and the Steamed Chicken w/ Chinese Sausage was also overcooked.

I would not come back here unless it was to try their Raw Fish Salad.  I heard that that is their specialty and based on the Yelp pictures, it looks good, but I was dining with my kids tonight and they weren't convinced.

For similar style chinese, I recommend "Ah Yee Lang Tong" over on Balboa & 45th.
author: Judy K.

description: I came here on a recommendation and it was okay.  The dining staff was very good and attentive, one of the best around.  I thought the dishes were okay but not spectacular.  I wasn't blown away.  For the prices I have gotten better elsewhere.  I was a bit disappointed, but I wouldn't say it was a bad experience, just so so.
author: Asana T.

description: I came here with eight older and always feisty Chinese ladies-- and they all enjoyed the meal! The house soup was good-- there was winter melon in it. And the famous chicken salad was refreshing and delicious but definitely overpriced considering that the chicken pieces are miniscule and that the salad is primarily comprised of crunchy rice (?) sticks. We very much enjoyed the chicken with mushrooms and the clams with black bean sauce. The beef dish was tasty and so were the seafood noodles. No complaints. The food was hearty and delicious. Most importantly, the harshest critics-- feisty, brutally honest Chinese grandmoms-- all left full and happy. Whew! What a relief.
author: Melissa K.

description:
we came here on a saturday night because all the other neighborhood chinese restaurants were full (mayflower, asia pearl etc)   the place was full when we arrived at around 7 and was empty when we left before 10.  there were 5 of us and the meal was cheap and we had tons of leftovers.

we had the raw fish salad (raw fish, cilantro, fried wonton/noodle things, other crunchy things, pickled ginger).  i was weary of eating raw fish in a chinese restaurant but it wasnt too bad.  im not a fan of fried wonton skin/noodle things.

we had the winter melon soup which a big steamed wintermelon.  my first bowl was a bit cold, not piping hot but overall it was good.  also kabocha with pork spare ribs - i liked the kabocha pumpkin!  a tchit gua with dried scallop sauce.  the aunties to them to cut the tchit gua thicker but when it came out it was thin.  it was tasty though.  also this chicken dish.  and a salty egg yolk crab.  next time we would go for the normal green onion ginger crab.  the salty egg yolk was almost nonexistent but there was a thick flour coating on the crab.
author: claudia y.

description:
Irish people love Chinese food.  Why?  Because we have massive families and you can actually take your whole mess o' kids and grandkids to Chinese food without a reservation and get a huge round table at which everyone can be equally scolded and guilted by the patriarch.  

Also, my grandparents were raised during (aka were defined by, aka couldn't stop talking about, aka were totally scarred by) the Depression, so they weren't going to pay a lot for that muffler.  Kirin is crazy-reasonable, which probably saved us from having our family dinners on the curb in front of a taco truck.

We started eating at Kirin back when dinosaurs roamed the earth.  Which was about the time we were chased out of our former Chinese place, called Mary's, because my grandfather left a tiny tip and the waiter freaked.  And while I totally agree that the food at Kirin is incredibly tasty and the authenticity deserves mad props, we were really just here because my grandfather could feed all 16 of us for like $40.  So lucky us that the food was excellent as well.  

I still have such a soft spot for this joint and I try to eat here whenever I'm in the neighborhood.  Thanks to the waiters of yesteryear for not yelling at us when they saw that Depression-era tip and just patiently waited for us to get my grandfather outside before we scrambled back with more money.
author: Rosie W.

description: Not sure why the city needs a place like this. The food is just ok, the prices are really high, especially for what you get and the service is baffling. You want to root for small places, but these guys seem like they are not even trying. With much better places a block in either direction, I can't say I would try it again.
author: Bob R.

description:
I walked up to Kirin for lunch with two of my friends yesterday and thought that this restaurant was going to be bad.  I was wrong and my friend Oliver was right. This place is good.

This place is your typical run of the mill Chinese restaurant but with great service.   A lot of Asian contractors come here for lunch.............so you know what  that means.  It's good, the portions are going to be huge and it's cheap.  The waiter comes out with a plate of napkins and a carafe of ice water.  Kinda caught me off guard.

I looked around and saw a bunch of  food coming out. and it looked fantastic  I don't know why we always order so much food.

Chicken Salad.  Looks very bland but tasted surprisingly fresh and flavorful

Dry fried chicken wings....Portions are huge.  A little too greasy for me but the flavor was there.  Capitol restaurant in Chinatown is a lot better and it's not even close to San Tung on Irving st. Overall the chicken wings are still good. I just had better.

Vegetables with cod fillet....this dish is not that good.  Didn't taste as fresh as it could be.  Will never order this one again.

Steamed pork with salted egg.  I would say one of the best dishes here.  You gotta have rice with this dish.  An oldie but goodie.

Pea shoots with garlic.............The portion on this dish were huge and it was one of my favorite dishes.

All 5 dishes came out to 41 dollars.  

I would come back to try the other items on their menu soon.
author: jason g.

description: I call this place my soul food fix!! Love the Chinese food here! The salt n pepper pork chops and salt and pepper fish are my favorite go to dishes . The chow fun is delicious as well! This place never let's me down ! The place is really like a family kind of restaurant . Great service and food ! Yum!
author: Judy C.

description:
KOI Palace was way too busy and the wait was too long, so had to settle for here. It actually wasn't bad. It was crowded with large groups for birthday and just family/friends gathering. Ambiance looked like any other Chinese restaurant and the servers were really nice and quick with everything.

Food!
*Rainbow Raw Fish Salad- It was a little too sweet for me and the portion was so big!! But for $26.00 for a small, it should be big. It had like fried wonton strips, those fried white noodle looking things, raw yellowtail pieces?. ginger, cilantro, peanut, onion, red pepper. This is really filling so don't eat too much
*Honey Walnut Prawn- I think I ate like 6 pieces of prawn and probably all the honey walnuts. It's was pretty damn good! Fried shrimp with mayo. Who wouldn't like that?
*Salt and pepper filet of Sole-This was also good. Didn't look oily at all. You're eating something healthy and bad at the same time so don't feel bad for eating this. Fish-healthy, being fried-bad!
*Golden Crispy Chicken-I think that was a whole order of chicken (in my pictures) and if it is, they gave a shit load of chicken! I liked the crispy skin of the chicken but the chicken itself was a little dry for my taste.
*Combo Pan Fried Noodle-Crispy noodle on the outside but inside is soft with the sauce. Loaded with seafood and meat ingredients. Really yummy!
*Conch sliced with vegetables and yellow chive- I didn't eat this one because I was way too full! But it looked delicious!
*Complementary Almond tofu with fruit salad-Nice and healthy.

A great place for Chinese dinner but parking sucks at night on weekends.
author: Juliane N.

description:
After a long hike and some quality outdoor time, some Chinese food sounded  good.  We were in the neighborhood and yelped this place.  Finding parking was a bit of a chore, but once we finally made it to the front door, we were seated quickly.   
The place was pretty full and the menu a little cryptic (when was the last time I ordered something besides mu shu shrimp?  embarrassing!) so we ordered corn soup ...and I don't remember what else we ordered...mostly because we were entertained and distracted by the elvis impersonator singing to a lovely blue haired lady named Grace.  We mentally retraced our steps - had we eaten any mushrooms with our breakfast?  The whole thing was a little surreal.  

The second time we came was Christmas day, again after trouncing about outside in the wind on the beach.  This time we had the good fortune of meeting up with 4 others so we could get the 6-person meal, with a side of the amazing corn soup.   

The chicken salad is amazing.    This with the corn soup is the new standard for Chinese dinner for me!  (though I won't completely shun the mu shu)   The other dishes were good, but I think that had we ordered a la carte, we would have chosen a lot more veggies and less breaded and beefy dishes.     For $20 per person, we feasted well and tried some new dishes, though next time we'll probably choose a la carte.
author: Maria C.

description: been coming here for years with family.  lives pretty close by, walking distance.  not the biggest place in the world. so pray that theres no banquets when you go.  there tends to be a lot of parties hosted on saturdays and sundays.  maybe weekdays too? who knows.  the waiters have been there forever since i was a kid.  always recognize the same people.  they know us and joke with us all the time.  great customer service in that aspect for an asian restaurant.  okay so food time.  quail - order in advance, chinese salad - order in advance, chicken skin with rice inside - order in advance, guava soup - order in advance.  okay so now that we got those out of the way, time to order the day of.  salt and pepper chicken wings are moist and hot and crispy and spicy! full of garlic too.  best wings ever.  well besides bon chon.  but those are different.  every other dish is pretty good.  better than average.  nothing superior to other places like noodle dishes and rice dishes.  parking is hard to find.  well easier now that meter is everywhere and everyone is too cheap to pay.  aint nobody got money for that!
author: Matthew G.

description:
We do the T. family round-up a few times a year. Most recently it was for Chinese New Year and I refuse to get anywhere other than Kirin. If it's not Kirin, I'm not goin'! So I'm a bit of a brat. But my family would never fight me on this because they know as well as I that Kirin has the best Mongolian Beef and Crispy Chicken in town. They can make my fav vege dish of tofu, dried mushroom, and pea-sprouts in gravy like no other, and it's in my hood! Plus, they give you the option of almond jello or red bean soup for dessert!

I almost forgot to mention that it is also clean! That in itself deserves five stars!
author: Deanna T.

description:
This place is haunted. 

We were sitting at one of the tables by the window (closest to the door), enjoying our salt and peppered squash and kung pao chicken when all of a sudden there was a huge BOOM. We looked over to the other table in the front of the store, the one directly to our left, when we realized that the lazy susan had rolled off the table and on to the floor. And there was no one sitting there.

Creeeepppyyyyyy. 

This was only my first time at Kirin and I only got to taste a few things, so let me tell you about those. They're not kidding when they describe the squash as salt and peppered... at times I felt like I was eating fries from McDonalds. They would have been AWESOME if just a little less salty. The kung pao chicken was pretty average (but then again, we were pretty safe by ordering that) and the pork fried rice was really good. We're talking even-better-two-days-later-for-lunch good. 

And if you're ever wondering where to buy a vacuum cleaner in the Outer Richmond, check out the men's bathroom at Kirin; they have every brand you can imagine.
author: Jared S.

description: The food was exceptional.  No fake scallops here.  Good fish.  Tasty meat.  Duck was awesome.
author: STEVE L.

description: Table for 10 family & cousins to chat & catch up. Still one of the top choices for our group. Ordered the special Yu Sang Salad(Everyone stopped talking until we ate it all). Then we had the juicy & crunchy jow gai yick, and Beef Tomato Curry Chow Mein, and garlic asparagus(Everyone loves garlic). Eclectic lunch but loved it!
author: GARY C.

description:
Pleasant. Very pleasant.
We just had 4 dishes for dinner; stuffed wontons, kung pao prawns, chow mein, and mandarin-style pork spareribs. First 3 were solid, if not remarkable. The spareribs, however, were certified kick-ass. Our servers were all really nice and attentive. We got a ton of food at very reasonable price. Definitely going again.
author: Raymond P.

description:
When you look into a Chinese restaurant, and see that is is actually full of Chinese people, you know in your heart that the food is good.  With so many mediocre places to nosh in the city, authenticity has taken the front seat in my decision-making-mobile.

   Every visit, I am intrigued by what everyone else seems to be eating.  Yes, most of it is meat, but the way it is presented fascinates me.  On the menu, I see things like squab (please tell me that's not pigeon), sea turtle, conch (shell?), goose feet, and an 88.00 bowl of soup that has to be ordered ahead of time.  None of this applies to me, but it's interesting nonetheless. 

   Never once have I been disappointed with the array of vegetarian dishes I have tried at Kirin.  Our server, who is wonderful, impeccable, and on-point every time we go, knew us after our first visit.  We came back the  second time almost a month and a half later, ordering a different dish and he said, "Oh, you're trying something else?"

   He truly remembered our faces and what we ate the last time we were there.  I remain very impressed by this.  His genuinity was the most amazing part... he really wanted us to enjoy it as much as the last thing we'd tried.

   I am just waiting for an occasion when I can go with a group and actually get to use the enormous tabletop Lazy Susans.  There's just not enough food to spin around when there's only 2 of you.

   Yum.
author: Lea N.

description:
Such good Cantonese food. Great prices. Good service. 

Lobster noodles are bomb! 

This is our favorite local Chinese take-out, eat-in. Always reliable and delicious - and makes me think why I ever bother cooking at all. 

I also think it says a lot about a place when the wait staff hasn't changed in years.
author: Lily H.

description:
+ Garlic pea sprouts. Awesome goodness. First dish to be cleared. 
+ Crab and corn soup. YUM. 
+ Walnut prawns. Nice portion and flavor. 
+ Salt and pepper spareribs. Variety of sizes. 
- Salted fish and tofu clay pot. But only because it wasn't what we ordered and we were too lazy/hungry to send it back. 
- Duck. We left half the plate on the table. 

They did seat us nine with a relatively short notice reservation on NYE. It's pretty pricey for a Chinese restaurant, but sounds like the lunch specials are a better deal.
author: Jenny L.

description:
Recently had my birthday dinner here.  And the food was as delicious.  My favorite dish is the Raw Fish Salad, which at $27.00 for a half order feeds 6 people.  On the rare occassion that I am craving this dish. . . they have done a smaller to-go version for $13.00. 
Of course there are other items on the dinner table, chicken, dried fried beans. . .but nothing compares to their chicken salad and raw fish salad. . will make it a point to try other dishes and report back.
author: Kea C.

description:
We had the salty fish/chicken in clay pot, filet of sole with mixed vegetables, and hot/sour soup.  

The sole was pretty decent, although it was pretty bland.  The salty fish was very fishy - definitely an acquired taste.  The hot/sour soup was pretty much what you'd expect - a little on the sour side...

Interesting service.  At times it felt like they were trying to make things a little more upscale, but it was all lost in the waiters who spent much of the time staring into space... sorry, it's just the truth.  It took effort to get the bill, but they snatched up the payment in no time.
author: Andrew S.

description: The food is overall good. On days where it is not busy the food comes out quick. However when there are alot of people then then the food comes out pretty slowly. The portions are big as well
author: Jeremy H.

description: best place to go to for lunch.  i love their HOUSE SPECIAL fried rice.  it has all kinds of seafood in it with chicken and beef.
author: Kurt N.

description:
Rainbow Chicken Salad, people!  

If you come for dinner, I highly recommend getting enough people together for the 6 person combo.  It was just me, girlie, and parents, but we decided to upgrade as the 6 person items looked more appetizing.  All the items in it were outstanding, except for the crab.  Tasted like the poor thing spent its whole life in a fishbowl.

We've also been here for lunch and passed the crab soup in favor of seafood won ton and Mongolian Beef.  The soup came in a bowl big enough to feed 3 or 4 people, and the beef was served on crispy glass noodles.  I honestly couldn't tell you which was better.

In summary, it's a lot of delicious food for not a whole lot of money.  I just don't get why they're always trying to push the crab on you.
author: John H.

description:
At this point in my life I need a lot of Kirin.  This is the best Chinese currently in the City.  Please do not take this statement lightly, I am Chinese and have eaten a lot of Chinese and will continue to do so.  If you have similar tastes in food then you will most definitely agree with me.

Hands down they have the BEST Salt&Pepper Spareribs I've ever had.  Lean (a lot Chinese Restaurants spareribs have a lot of fat), salty, garlicky, mildly spicy, deep fried goodness... these spareribs practically melt in your mouth.  If you hate everything else on the menu but love the spareribs as I do then Kirin will be worth it.

Someone else mentioned the Fish Salad which is very good.  The fish always seems fresh, tender, and the salad adds a refreshing sweet, mildly pickled flavor which makes this a great starter.

Clams with garlic.  Simple yet delicious.  A platter of clams is served with little mounds of garlic and green onions in the shell... I'm sure there are some other ingredients but I'm not sure what they are, it's good.

I always order pea sprouts whenever I eat Chinese b/c it just has to be that way.  Remember, if there are tons of Chinese people eating at the Chinese restaurant then you probably want to give it a try.  It gets a little packed and they close at 9.  I actually went there with a large party at 8:50 and they served us without any issues.
author: Micah W.

description: Their chinese dishes were good, nicely decorated and just like any other GOOD chinese restaurant.  What makes this place unique and good is their Stuffed Chicken dish.  I have never eaten that before and it was delicious!  They have got to market that dish because I don't know any other restaurant that can make such a dish an art form!
author: Joseph C.

description:
Kirin is a solid place to get Cantonese cuisine.  Don't go there if you are looking for "spicy" because most Cantonese dishes are more subtle.

We go there fairly often, whether for large group banquets or just two of us.  Henry, the owner, usually greets you in front.  The waiters are always friendly, especially Sam who, as another reviewer mentioned, speaks English, Cantonese and Spanish.

The raw fish salad is a Kirin signature dish which is best to order ahead of time by phone if you really want to make sure they have it.  This is a refreshing dish with crunchy textures from crispy noodles and pickled vegetable pieces.

Yesterday my wife and son and I had lunch at Kirin.  We ordered the West Lake Beef soup, salt and pepper squid, bitter melon with beef in black bean sauce and Chinese long bean minced with ground pork and mushrooms.  

The soup is a favorite of my son's.  It has a clear, fresh broth with bits of ground beef and egg whites.  A real comfort food dish.  

Kirin's kitchen makes a tasty salt and pepper squid.  Eat it as soon as it is served while the lightly battered squid is still sizzling hot.  And make sure that with each piece of squid you eat a little of the sliced jalapeno and scallion.  Tasty and a little tangy!

If you have never tried Chinese bitter melon, check it out.  Yes the melon is bitter --but that's OK -- it's not TOO bitter!  And it is a classic Cantonese taste, especially with the black bean sauce.  Kirin also serves the same dish with frog legs instead of beef.  Also very tasty.

Most caucasians probably would overlook the Chinese long bean with mushrooms and pork.  But my Chinese wife spotted it long ago and now it is a favorite of mine.  The beans are cut into pieces about half an inch long and "chowed" (stir fried) with the other ingredients.    This bean has a nutty flavor and the texture of the dish is crunchy.

Overall, Kirin is one of most reliable Cantonese restaurants in the Richmond District.  Its menu is vast.  So if you want some advice, ask Henry or Sam for something unusual that you might have overlooked.  There are also the daily "wo choy" specials which are often written only in Chinese on the wall.  Ask about those too.  I guarantee  that you will NOT find the usual dishes that non-Chinese people order.

Prices at Kirin are very reasonable. A great place to take out-of-town visitors for a highly varied and tasty meal!  And it's OK to bring your own wine.  The waiters will open it for you and serve in the proper glasses.
author: Rich S.

description:
They use fresh mushrooms for their black mushrooms and mustard green dish. It's definitely one of the best i've ever had. If you like mushrooms, you've GOT to try the dish here. 

Personally I feel the chicken stuffed with sticky rice is a little overrated. I mean it's good, but wheres the chicken meat? I don't think the layer of chicken skin covering the rice and its presentation as a whole chicken is enough for me to separate it from just regular old sticky rice.
author: Will T.

description:
I've been here twice with my family to celebrate birthdays. It's one of those pricey places where you can really taste the quality of what you're paying for. 

For the appetizer, we always order this raw fish salad. It's a little sweet and comes with a variation of raw fish, peanuts, and those crispy things. We also order this thing that comes out looking like a whole chicken....but it is actually stuffed with sticky rice. it's so unique...but really good. The lobster was also really meaty...unlike some places that just give you nothing but shells. Even their sliced beef with vegetables was amazing...it was really soft and tender. 

The waiter is really nice to us. He's always helping us taking pictures and cracking jokes with us. Parking on Geary is a little tough too...but it's worth it!
author: Allan M.

description:
I encouraged my brother to have his daughter's 1 yr bday party gathering here cus of all the positive reviews on Yelp...and the fact that I was also tired of buffets and Moonstar.  This was a gamble since I had never been here before and trusting the reviews of fellow foodies.  He had never tried it before either but decided to go for it.

In short, IT TURNED OUT FANTASTIC!  The staff was very accommodating the entire evening and the food was every bit as good as other Yelpers have said it was.  The portions were pretty big too!  We got there early to set up balloons and have the cake put in their fridge.  Since we reserved tables, they said it was also ok to bring our own 2 liter soft drinks, etc.  

The Rainbow Raw Fish Salad was our first course and it impressed my table and the people at surrounding tables as well.  The lemon chicken was very tender...better than I had had in years.  The steamed fish was very fresh and also received compliments all around (our server de-boned it and reassembled the fish afterwards).  The lobster tasted good as well as other dishes.  The squab (raised pigeon or quail...who the hell knows) was VERY tender and probably the best I had ever tasted....and Ive eaten that dish A LOT.

The only dish we had a problem with was their soup (imitation shark fin I think or something that looked like it).  It was bland/watery and the servers didn't bring out the red vinegar for it which we had to ask for.

Other than that, everything was great.

Thanks fellow Yelpers for providing a great location for my niece's bday party!
author: Gilbert C.

description: I came here for a family dinner, but when three of us ended up having to go to the hospital for food poisoning, I think i won't be returning here.  I used to think this was an ok place, but certainly not worth the health risks.  Very unsanitary!
author: marcus h.

description: We order over 6 different dishes and all of them were really really good. This the place to go if you like Chinese food.
author: Anthony D.

description:
Came here on my own, which was probably my first mistake.  This is not a place you come to as a single diner, this is a place you come to with 10 friends.  Service was fine, but the beef stew I had was a little too chewy.  Actually, a lot too chewy.  This was the cheapest beef cut they found, and not much was done to improve the fact the cut was so tough.

Next time I'll come with a bunch of people, and I won't get the beef stew.
author: Eric M.

description:
Because I live on the East Coast, I've only been to this Asian fusion restaurant once; however, I have to say that it was seriously one of the most memorable meals of my lifetime.

We went for my sister-in-law's wedding rehearsal dinner, and ordered an array of seafood dishes. One by one the dishes came out, all piping hot, tasty, and lacking that usual Chinese food grease that weighs you down for the next 24 hours. It was good food that you just knew wa good for you too. Not one thing we ordered disappointed us in any way. I can only say that about a handful of restaurants I've been to.

The seared salt and pepper sea scallops is a life-changing dish. It's seriously that good. I've devoted my life to getting back here one day to eat those succulent, sizzling scallops marinated in warm peppery goodness once again.

The service was top-notch (although they of course knew we were a special party), and the restaurant is decorated in a spare fashion, but it's in a casual yet classy sort of way. The high ceilings really help the whole dining experience. Amazing food, priced as Chinese food should be priced. Highly, highly recommend.
author: Chu C.

description:
Six of us came here for Chinese New Year's eve dinner.  We made our reservation on Friday and they were able to accommodate us on a Sunday with an 8pm reservation.  

We had the following dishes, and it was more than enough for the 6 of us.  The bill was also reasonable at $16/person including tax and tips.  Service was decent and wait time was short.

-Lobster noodles (fabulous - very very fresh noodles and lobster)
-Crispy chicken, half size (fabulous - very tasty)
-Honey walnuts with prawn (this was ok - i've had better elsewhere)
-Chinese broccoli (fabulous - very very tender!)
-Mushroom w/bok choy (good - a little dried at the caps, but flavor was good)
-Fish maw w/crab soup (good)

Good solid, Hong Kong style chinese food.
author: Mon L.

description:
My family has been going here for a long time now, and when I think of Kirin the only thing that pops into my mind is; SOLID. It's just overall solid Chinese food, nothing is outrageously good and the food is never bad, ever. What I do like about Kirin though is that they remember you from the last time, and the portions they give you regardless if they know you or not are enormous. Sure they're enormous because you're ordering family style, but seriously some family style places don't even give you half as much as Kirin does. 

Tips and Pointers:
-Everything on the menu is solid, good, chinese food
-Seating can be a drag because it's always packed (but that's a good thing right?)
-Parking is horrendous on Geary, but that's to be expected
-Prices are cheap, dirt cheap

[APPROVED]
author: Eric T.

description:
I hear a lot of people tell me that this is one of the more quality Chinese restaurants and I guess it's true.  I didn't really believe it before but I've actually come here on numerous occasions and after thinking about a little bit more, they are indeed pretty good.  Seems the food is not as oily as other places.  The service is outstanding for a Chinese restaurant.  All of the waiters really work as a team and you can see them being extremely organized as they do their thing around the dining room.  

They have a couple of "Star" dishes that many people go there for.  The Rainbow Salad with either Raw Fish or Chicken.  A lot of people come here especially for Chinese New Year's Seventh Day Dinner (Everyone's Birthday) for that.  But any other day, it's definitely popular.  

And the Winter Melon Soup where they put the soup in a real Wintermelon is also very popular as you can see on a nightly basis if you eat here often.  This is something you need to pre-order in advance though so if you go and want that, make sure to call at least a day in advance....
author: Mark W.

description: The mongolian beef here is ok. The last time I came here I asked them if the rice was in the to go bag and they said yes. I got home and it wasn't there. Service is like any chinese restaurant so none but the food is decent.
author: Darius A.

description:
BEST SPRIMP WON TON SOUP EVER!

My sister and I were killing time while my car was at Jiffy Lube, which is across the street, and we decided to grab some lunch here. We shared the Won Ton Soup and an order of Broccoli Beef. Our bill was $14 and we had enough left overs for at least one more meal.

The soup was amazing. There wasn't too much in it. Just prawns, wontons and some onions. The broth had enough flavor that you could have eaten it alone. The broccoli beef was also good, with big pieces of broccoli.

You can't beat that price or the portion size. The decor is your average Chinese place but I recommend it if you're in the area.
author: Jackie G.

description: Food was terrific and Authentic (right down to the full 1/2 fried chicken with head and jelly fish with beef tendon). This is what Chinese food is all about. Incredible value - definitely order the family meal - we ordered the 4 person meal and it was enough food for 6. Ambience was standard for this kind of restaurant.  I will definitely go back and bring out of town guests.
author: Ben T.

description:
This place is highly overrated.  My friend and I ordered two seafood dishes.  A special crab dinner, and prawns with salt and pepper. Neither were worth eating.  The complimentary soup was nice, but the service was bad.  They didn't offer us water, and then when we asked the waiter he still would not bring any. I also ordered rice which didn't come till half way through our meal.  

I hope you think about going somewhere else next time you want great Chinese.

4/10/09
author: Rob S.

description:
Really good food, service is good also. Prices are decent. Many of their specialty dishes are on the high range for Chinese food but well worth it. Most of the staff has a pretty good handle on English and the owner is often at the front, taking reservations and seating people. This place gets very busy on most evenings and I would reccomend reservations if you're going around or on a holiday.

I've been quite a few times for dinner and once for lunch, most everything was really tasty and their portions are a good size. The dish that is ordered by nearly all the tables is the Rainbow Raw Fish Salad or the chicken version of it. It's a dish comprised of pickled ginger, crunchy bean thread noodles, peanuts, thinly shredded cabbage, bean sprouts, green onions and raw fish or chicken. Very nice light flavor and not too crunchy despite the fried noodles. The other dishes that are popular are the salt and pepper chicken wings, sweet pea sprouts with garlic sauce (really yummy and it's the only all veggie dish that is a chef specialty), clams in black bean sauce, crispy fried whole or half chicken, and any of the whole fish dishes. There are many more popular dishes but this is all I can remember at this point. 

The day's house soup is automatically served with dinner or lunch. It's usually something very Cantonese like watercress in a pork broth, nothing very heavy. And oranges are served with the delivery of the check along with some fortune cookies. They do offer red bean soup or almond jello (I love almond jello!) but I don't recall if that's on the house or if you're charged for selecting either of those two.

All in all I can say that meals here are usually very satisfying and never disappointing.
author: cyndi L.

description:
Can't give it five stars yet, because I haven't eaten there, just take-out.  A lot of the take-out or delivery places in my 'hood, the outer richmond, give you about half as much food as you'd get if you ate there, but not Kirin.  

They don't deliver, but if you haul your lazy ass over there and have your ride circle the block, it's faster.  The food was ready ten minutes after I ordered it. 

Minus one star for the Mandarin beef.  I ended up eating most of Shannon's salt and pepper cod, which was delicious.  And make sure you ask for rice, or you won't get it.

The flavors are just right, none of that MSG taste or the excessive thickener in the soups like you sometimes get.  Got some in my fridge, pretty much all the time.
author: Jimmy C.

description:
I wish I could rate the food here, but the service was so rude that we left before being seated.  Two of us arrived on a Saturday for lunch around 12:30pm. All of the tables were full, but there were only a few parties waiting ahead of us.  It took 10 minutes for someone to greet us at the door.  When they saw that we were a party of 2, they scoffed, and said it would be 45 minutes.  Since we had heard good things about the restaurant, we decided to wait.  After about 20 minutes, we asked them for an update, and to our disgust, we found out that they did not even put us on the list and it was going to be at least an hour.  At that point, we decided to leave.  While we were waiting, another party of 4 received similar treatment.

Bottom line, do not go there if you have a party of 4 or less.  They will not be interested in your business.
author: Stacy N.

description: My wife and I had a friend in town visiting for a few days, and we decided to try Kirin, I've eaten here before. Salt & pepper pork chops, prawns with snow peas, Mongolian beef, hot and sour soup, some type of combo fried rice. I love all the salt and pepper dishes, especially pork chops, and Kirin's was excellent. Mongolian beef really good, beef was exceptionally tender, and I like the fact that they only used green onions, rather than a mixture of green and yellow onion. There location is far enough out on Geary that parking was close by and easy. The waiters were pleasant to us, we were about the only non-Asian customers present, but were made to feel welcome.........tasty food and I will come back.
author: Bob I.

description:
I have been searching for a new restaurant after my favorite chinese restaurant Dragon House closed.  We decided to try Kirin after reading all the great review at Yelp.  

The service was great but the food was a little pricey and was just ok.   We will probably give them another try before we write them off.
author: L C.

description: We had minced beef & egg white soup,  pea sprout with fish, salt and pepper squid and chow mein here.  The soup was so so- the broth didn't have too much flavor.  The pea sprout with fish was excellent!!  The fish was very fresh and the vegetables were done perfectly!  OMG the Salt and pepper squid was SOOOOO crispy and sinfully good!  I couldn't stop popping one in my mouth!   The squid was super fresh, too.  The chow mein was the thick kind and it was just OK.  Overall it was a very pleasant lunch with great service!
author: RW G.

description:
I'm a big fan of mapo tofu and Kirin serves a mean dish!  Superman likes to get his whole fish.  The service is excellent and each meal comes with the soup of the day and a dessert of your choice.  Free food!  Yes!  I highly recommend giving this place a spin!

My fortune:
"You will make many changes before setting down happily."

Superman's fortune:
"Remember the past to help you in the future."
author: Christine H.

description: We gathered here for our annual family reunion. Here are tips to save you time: drive a compact car if you have one. Parking is sparse. We were fortunate to find a spot off of Geary. I have not tried this, but if parking is impossible, go towards the left of the restaurant, there is a high school there. That would be your next best bet. It was going to be our life saver if we couldn't find anything remotely close. It's only about 4 blocks from the restaurant anyway. Now, getting to the good stuff! The food was great. Here's what you need to order: chicken salad (yeah it sounds trite, but you won't regret it, this place is known for this salad), chicken lettuce cups, seafood soup with fried wontons, chicken wings (you don't regret it! well you might... :), and the tofu dish with the mushrooms. There were tons of other plates that we ordered, but I couldn't try them all because I was so full! The portions are good too.
author: Ally W.

description: I've only eaten here for large banquets, which they apparently do a lot of. Everything is good as you'd expect. One specialty is this raw fish salad (I have no idea what it's called) that comes with fried bits and sashimi-esque raw fish that is quite delicious and unusual, but very refreshing. They also do the deep fried chicken stuffed with sticky rice (i.e. with sticky rice instead of meat, inside fried chicken skin) which is definitely worth trying if you don't mind a little grease. A good place for large groups, good prices.
author: Mike L.

description: Mediocre Chinese food for above average prices. Dishes were either way too sweet, way too salty, or totally bland. So many other choices in the area, please go elsewhere. I honestly don't know why people come here.
author: David L.

description:
if your'e visiting sf, this place is a MUST-TRY.  their menu is very extensive. they do everything from peking duck to beef chowfun (dry or wet).  They're good for big or small parties.  

I especially go for their lunch menu.  Only a few places still do a house(complimentary soup aka lai tong) nowadays and this is one of them.  The portions are more than generous - so come hungry!

if you come for dinner don't forget to order the salt and pepper crab!
author: Thomas L.

description: I am a huge fan of Mongolian beef, and it has taken me a few Chinese restaurants but I finally found one that I enjoy and has a good Mongolian beef. Although it is a tad spicy still the best i've gotten, and if you don't like it as spicy as they make it just tell them to tone down on the chili peppers. Another great item here was the Lemon Chicken. At first my gf started eating the chicken without the lemon sauce and was wondering why it wasn't lemony, and thought we had been given the wrong item. Then she noticed the huge container of lemon sauce to pour all over the chicken and it was GLORIOUS, so don't forget the sauce!
author: James H.

description:
mmm... i remember coming here when this place first opened. the owner used to be a waiter at this other chinese restaurant called Happy Immortal, but it closed down a long time ago. anyways, this waiter grabbed the cooks and opened up this tasty delight known as Kirin.

the waiters there are great! they are always very welcoming and greets us by name (i'm not sure if it's like that for everyone... we go there semi-often, usually on special occassions).
