there is one waiter there that goes by the name of Sam. not only does he speak chinese and english fluently, but if you are so inclined, you can also order your food in spanish and he'll be there to take your order without any problems. he's also really funny, if that's what you're looking for in a server to enhance your dining experience.

i would have to say that this place is cleaner than most chinese restaurants, without sacrificing the quality of its food. because we all know that (normally), the dirtier the restaurant is, the better the food because they are too busy making good eats to be worried about a clean bathroom and whatnots. this is what makes Kirin so great!
author: Nathan J.

description: The service here is truly the best I've seen in the city. I came here for my graduation celebration dinner and we never had to ask the waiters to do anything for us. The food is always amazing to boot.
author: Clarissa S.

description: Fried Chicken Wings are the best I have ever had in a chinese restuarant and the best you'll ever have if you try it!!!
author: Cathy N.

description: I've been here over a dozen times.  One of my favorite family style Chinese restaurants in the Richmond.  If you have a large family, you'll know how hard it is to get 2-3 tables for 20 to 30 people.  They rarely overbook so our family always get our tables on time.  The service is better than most busy Chinese restaurant.  We usually order the set meal and add three additional dishes.  They serve tradition Chinese food and Americanize Chinese food, so everyone is always happy.  Btw, the Chinese chicken salad from here is one of the best I've ever had.  I do recommend calling to make reservations as they do get very busy during the weekends and holiday.
author: hello k.

description:
My friends had been raving about some rainbow salad so we decided it was time to see just how good it really is.  No doubt - it was YUM and so was everything else we ordered!

- Rainbow chicken salad - Very yum!  It's a sweet, tangy salad.  A large was plenty to feed 8 hungry bodies as an appetizer
- Lettuce wraps - Mmmm.  Chicken and saugage, side hoisin sauce, all in a cool piece of lettuce.  
- Wintermelon soup - Perfect for the cool night.  Fresh, not too salty, not too bland.  
- Chicken wings - Oily, yes.  But delicious!  
- Beef with Vegi - We picked chinese broccoli.  The beef was sweet and tender, very good.
- Rice Stuffed Chicken - This was a very new dish for me.  It's a fried chicken stuffed with the sticky rice (usually found in a leaf as a dim sum dish).  It was awesome!  
- Noodles - The restaurant was kind enough to give us a complimentary bowl of noodles.  I'm not sure what type it was.  All it really had were shitake mushrooms and lemon grass.  It was so simple and so good!  
- Almond Jello - A perfect way to end the evening.  They asked us if we'd like dessert, and we asked for the almond jello thinking it would be charged.  It ended up being on the house, which made it taste even better.  ;)

The restaurant itself is clean, which is very important to me.  It's a good size, not a small hole in the wall.  Service is great. 

I was quite impressed.  It's not often that I could go to yet another Chinese restaurant and try foods I've never tasted.  The bill came out to a $152 with tax and tip.  Not too shabby for 8 people.  

I'll definitely go back.
author: Stella K.

description: I was in the neighborhood and decided to give this place a try. What a mistake. While the service was prompt and friendly the food was awful. The sweet and sour shrimp was disappointing at best. The shrimp tasted like they had been frozen for months and were not properly cleaned. They were limp and covered in soggy batter. The vegetable plate was bland and covered in a thick gloss of flavorlessness. The chicken and corn soup was acceptable. There are so many good places to get Chinese food in San Francisco so you best keep walking down Geary and find another.
author: Michelle C.

description:
I had high expectations coming into this restaurant. After reading reviews saying that there Stuffed Chicken with Sweet Rice is the dish of choice i decided to bring my sister and grandma to give it try. After dining i have to say i was greatly disappointed. We ordered the Stuffed Chicken, Steamed Catfish, and a Ong-Choy. The stuffed chicken was not what i expected...the skin of the chicken was suppose to be crispy, but instead it was very chewy with a slight crunch. I've only had this dish a few times in other restaurants, and i remember it having much more chicken meat, but for Kirin, it came with an extremely thin layer of meat (almost like if your lucky you'll get a piece with a bit of chicken, otherwise it is just skin), the chewy skin, and the stuffed rice (which was not bad)...but for $33 this stuffed chicken to me was just not worth it. I understand it might have required a lot of work to prepare it, but i am greatly disappointed in this dish. 

The catfish and Ong-Choy was okay. The catfish did not taste fresh, i'm not sure if they gave us a dead fish or maybe it was overcooked, but the texture is just not what i expected. The Ong-Choy i would say is probably the best dish we had. However, these too dishes were very greasy, but i can't complain because that's usually how Chinese cooking is in restaurants. 

I don't write many reviews on yelp, but with this restaurant having an average 4 star rating, i just have to inform others if they plan to give this place a try. The dishes are really overpriced, so you guys can make the decision. 

If you want better Chinese food i recommend Hong Kong Lounge which is a few blocks down on Geary, i've never been disappointed dining there. So yall can make the decision about dining at Kirin, but for the price, i'd rather you go to Hong Kong Lounge and get much better food.
author: Harrison C.

description: chinese new year's banquet, festival like atmosphere where along side us a six-table family association, packed,; now the food: started off with a signature chinese chicken salad done with elan, afterwards; course after course, beautiful, BUT BLAND, a situation I encountered a few years ago ... as my uncle said, could adding some seasoning killed them?  So this is the go-to spot for beautiful bland chinese food and those of us on a low-salt, heart healthy chinese cuisine diet ... for those raised on MSG, avoid like the plague ... for us foodies:  go elsewhere, hi chloe!
author: tim y.

description:
so i NEVER review chinese restaurants. they're all the same to me, really. on my last trip home, we were having a family dinner here and i must say, i was sort of impressed. the food was pretty good, the most impressive one being the rainbow fish salad. that shit was HUGE! we ordered the cheapest banquet meal plus 2 more dishes and it was more than enough food for 12 people, although we should have remembered there are people that eat like freakin BIRDS in my family. 

why the 4 stars? i have never been to a chinese place where the service was seriously on top of their game. serving the salad and soup so the entire plate/bowl was empty and it didn't have to be left on the lazy susan. refilling our tea right after we put the lid up. and the most impressive (to my family at least) was at the end of the meal, the waiter actually stacked ALL of our dishes into one huge leaning tower of dishes without even dropping it. 

now i don't voluntarily go to a chinese restuarant by choice. but if my family wanted to eat here again for sunday dinner, i wouldn't be adverse to it like how i am to eating at best panda, oh EXCUSE ME, it's empero taste now on 40th.

but yeah, kirin, you're alright.
author: Melanie C.

description: I went here with my boyfriend and his family for dinner one night! good atmosphere and i really enjoyed the food! the location is pretty easy to find as well. I can't remember what i had, because the family ordered, but it seemed like authentic chinese food to me. Nothing i've ever tasted before, but definitely tasty and not as oily as some other chinese restaurants i've eaten at. This place also seems like a good restaurant for families.
author: Kristine C.

description: Kirin is still a solid standby, but the last visit did find that some of our familiar favorites were a bit wanting in flavor and finish. Then finally the denouement long suffering long life noodles were seriously overcooked, funny tasting and  not appealing - to render any kind of noodle unpalatable for my nomnivorous appetite for all things noodley is rather a sad state of things.
author: GIR ..

description: My aunt had her 81st birthday here. Kinda small place with about 20 tables. Decor is non existent other than afew pictures on the wall but you go here for the food. I gotta say the food was excellent here. It was something like a 9 course meal with the most memorable dish the walnut shrimp and the winter melon soup. These two are a must order if you go here. I was stuff for days . Staff was friendly and more than accommadating. Parking could be tough but its tough everywhere in San Francisco.
author: Mister J.

description:
as a disclaimer, and to set the background tone - i am a bay area ABC, i do love places such as D&A, VIP, ABC, Lucky Fortune, and Golden Gate Dimsum.  if none of these places mean anything to you, then it won't matter.

i do enjoy the chinese chicken salad.  the winter melon soup is also quite good.  the mushrooms are also pretty good.

the rest is passable on a semi normal basis.  or maybe its just sub passable, but my younger cousins seem to love this place, thus our family keeps coming back.  it's a fairly ABC/safe/friendly type place.  i wouldn't necessarily bring my in-laws here . . . but it is what it is.  decent chinese food for cheap.
author: Jason J.

description: Kirin was a major let-down for me.  I ordered a beef dish, and some chow mein, both of which were overly greasy.  The beef was rubbery and the noodles were tasteless for the most part.  I'm spoiled by New Oceanic in Livermore though, so that definitely skews my review.  Overall though, the food was palatable and decent for across the street from the ol' apartment.
author: Corey D.

description: Solid Chinese restaurant.  My favorites here include: fried whole flounder with ginger and garlic sauce (I prefer the sauce on the side), sugar pea sprouts with garlic sauce, mandarin spare ribs (but it can be fatty so I have to weed through the pieces to find the meaty ones)...and for some reason, I really enjoy their almond jello for dessert!  Special dishes (like a couple of the ones listed above) can be pricier ($10-30), but the basics are in the $7 range.
author: Joyce L.

description: Clean and friendly Chinese restaurant.  Excellent service compared to other Chinese restaurants I have been to.  My family had the $48 dinner for 4.  Not much of a wait for our food.  The flounder over veggies and mandarin ribs were tasty.  Choice of almond jello or sweet red bean soup for dessert.  Their red bean soup had whole red beans and tapoica.  Definitely not watered down!
author: Mick S.

description: Good country style restaurant.  The shrimp are sweet, the prices reasonable, and also a good place for clay pots.
author: Kapeli M.

description:
I've been to these restaurant too many times to remember, so it's about time that i reviewed it.  We're actually coming here for our Chinese New Year dinner and I'm very excited about it.  

One disclaimer I have is that my parents know the owners and people that work here so they always treat us well.  But all that means at a Chinese restaurant is they don't charge you for drinks.  The service is still the same.  

One of my favorite Chinese restaurants in San Francisco.  You must get the Raw Fish salad!  It's one of my favorites on the menu.  There's also a sticky rice that's wrapped in a deep fried chicken skin.  Everything else is really good too.  We always order all sorts of stuff and it's always great quality and you don't feel like you ate a lot of grease or msg at the end of the night.  

Come here and you're getting really authentic Chinese food at a reasonable price.
author: Scott L.

description: Living down the block I have eaten take out here many times.  My all time favorite is the mongolian beef over rice is a must.  My sisters love the tomato beef chow mein with extra sauce.  Yummers.
author: Allison T.

description: We came earlier this year to eat and get together with some friends and ran into another set of friends dining that same evening with their family. The food is decent, they sort of hurry you along.  I would rather eat at K&L or China First if you made me choose because I don't think the food is that memorable.
author: Ry T.

description:
edit- this is my favorite Chinese restaurant so far. i may be alittle biased because my mom knows most of the workers... but besides that, they make awesome Chinese food! the dishes are never drowning in oil, and they give you big portions to share family style. i also like how there's never that long of a wait. the prices aren't bad either=)

-------------------
mmm rainbow fish salad... i can eat plate full of this stuff.. minus the peanuts they put in it. but minus one point for bad parking!! i had to park 6 blocks away, which seems especially long at night time and minus one point for putting us in a corner and forgetting to give us our rice! but add a point for the free soup and red bean dessert. yum.=)
author: christy w.

description: I usually come here with a group of friends. The have 5 tables than can accommodate a party of 10 and 4 that seat 8 so no waiting here. Food and service is consistantly good. I like the clams in black bean sauce, honey walnut prawns, salt and pepper pork chops etc. Everything is pretty good here and reasonably priced. You can choose your dessert usually almond jello or red bean or oranges along with fortune cookies too.
author: bo c.

description: it is somewhat Asian fusion. Food was filling, lemon chicken was good, desert was a mix of jello and red bean soup, very interesting, have no complaints :D.
author: Jon K.

description: Decent little place, not to pricey. A touch greasy but that is forgiveable. There are other places id rather go. but if I want chinese food and dont want to go far its the spot.
author: Tony M.

description: I love their tomato beef fried noodles. Not very many places can get it right. Kirin can. Another favorite is the Mongolian beef. I have traditional Chinese food all the time, but still crave these "Americanized" things, and this place does not disappoint. Very consistent.
author: ann t.

description: A pretty solid chinese restaurant for authentic cantonese food.  Its funny, a lot of chinese families come here for big gatherings and you notice that everyone here orders basically the same dishes at every table.  Prices are decently priced and you get qualtiy tasty food for what you pay for.  Reason for the 3 stars is that I really didnt have anything here that shot out as really amazing.  But to be clear, I love coming here everytime I do come.  Just nothing really really amazing.  Just a solid chinese rest. you would expect to find in the richmond district.
author: Charles C.

description: Decent Chinese food on Geary, and this place usually doesn't get as crowded as some of the other restaurants nearby....
author: J K.

description:
So I've been to Kirin many many many times over the years because it's my grandma's favorite place to take the family and well...she floats the bill, so enough said.  
Henry and the rest of the staff are the best when it comes to service in a chinese restaurant.  They're very attentive, exchange your dirty plate in the middle of the meal with a nice clean one, and the food is very good.  That's the combo that will earn 5 stars! 
Some of the fav's that we get are the chicken salad (I know most reviews talk about the raw fish salad, but the chicken one is just as good!), honey walnut prawns, fried chicken wings, chicken stuffed with sticky rice, crispy chicken, peking duck and lobster.   
I know these are pretty basic staples of a chinese meal, but they do these dishes really well and consistant!
One thing that is a minus, but not on the restaurant, is the parking.  If you're not there early, it can be a little tricky finding parking on the weekends.
author: Greg C.

description:
This place is an off-shoot of the now closed Happy Immortal restaurant in the outer richmond.  

We come here for lunch all the time and all the food is great, better than most chinese restaurants, but recently some of the dishes were not edible and they realized it and did nothing.
author: kenny l.

description:
everything was so so 
noodles were bland
chicken stuffed with rice -- where's the chicken? 
and the raw fish salad? too much japanese ginger 

all that for $70? too expensive.
author: leslie y.

description: living just a few blocks away, this chinese resto makes for a GREAT place for dinner take-out.  a plus of take-out is that they let you order from the lunch special menu. end result: $6.50 for 3 meals' worth of pineapple fried rice. totally continuing my take-out routine at this lil chinese gem. YUM.
author: Meg M.

description: YUMMY!  My favorite Chinese Restaurant.  Everytime I visit Kirin, I've got to have the rainbow raw fish salad, this is a signature dish and you can't find it else where.  The spicy deep fried chicken wings is tasty and the batter is not too thick, just perfect.  The deep fried wonton and deep fried squid is also a good one.  There are so many of my favorite dishes , I just can't name it all.  This place does get crowded on the weekends, so reservation is recommended.
author: Sam C.

description: The fried won ton soup is a MUST HAVE for me here. I also like their salt and pepper chicken wings. I usually go elsewhere when I want chinese food. I only come here when i'm craving fried won ton soup!
author: Karine L.

description: One of the last traditional family Chinese restaurants in San Francisco!  The place to eat on Chinese New Year!  Fish Salad, Tomato Beef Chow Mein (HK style!), just a couple of consistantly delicious dishes!  Enjoy and Gung Hay Fat Choy Everyone!
author: Gary L.

description: so i'm giving it three stars and not four or five because although the food is tasty and it is very very tasty (yummm general chicken over white rice)...the service is BLEH. the servers are sorta rude and short with you, so i've eaten there a few times. but i would definitely recommend take out if you can. so food=tasty and very very worth it, service=wack (except for the manager...the guy in the suit..who's the only nice person in there)
author: Sandi V.

description: YUM YUM YUM!!!! my lemon chicken was crispy and moist and lemony and delicious! and it came with a huge container of lemon glaze to pour on top...drrrooolllll...and my bf's mongolian beef was tasty and very spicy! egg rolls were huge and yummy too!
author: N. M.

description: Kirin is just like chinese home style cooking.  There has not been a dish that I did not enjoy.  They have been very accommodating for my mother-in-law who needs to watch her sodium intake.  The dishes taste the same if you come with just five or eight banquet tables.  The chef is consistent with the flavoring.  Kirin is very clean including the bathroom.   Our favorite dishes are hung tao won-ton, salt/pepper chicken wings, rainbow chicken salad, and assorted clay pots.
author: Arlene L.

description: Pretty decent food for the price they charge.  I've been eating at this restaurant (both in house and take out) for about five years, and the food has been fairly consistent in taste and quality - not terribly exciting, but not inedible either.  The portions are fairly big and the prices are reasonable.  Good place to go if you need cheap eats and refuse to eat at McD's or like establishments.
author: J H.

description: Back in the late 80s...yes, the 80s, this place was some place special. Now, it's a dump! I assume this place got new owners.The paint is coming off, the wood is rotting, and you get the since the owners don't really care about what it looks like inside, it all seems patched up. Don't even get me started on the bathrooms! Judging from the tables seating 6 or more, they care more about quantity rather than quality. The service almost looked disgusted to see us. Not sure why. The food is just ok. Nothing special in my book. My girlfriend actually got sick after the meal. This after telling them she was allergic to seafood! They might be using the same pots to cook seafood with regular food without cleaning it first! Dangerous for people with food allergies!! It's sad too. We really used to like going there. Not next time, not ever. Farewell Kirin. I liked you better when you took pride in yourself.
author: Joshua B.

description: pretty good food. i didnt think chinese restaurants served raw fish but apparently this one did. i thought it was pretty good, but it was a little pricey. another notable dish was the geoclam with vegetables. personally, i love them. many people who do not like exotic foods might not. i would recommend it if you do. overall, i enjoyed my meal at this restaurant.
author: Jimmy N.

description: I'm a bit hard to please when it comes to Chinese food: I don't care for the traditional fare you often see in American Chinese restaurants, like fried rice, won ton soup, and egg rolls. After reading the reviews of the Kirin on yelp, my daughter and I decided to try the place. The menu focuses on Chinese seafood, and if the entrees don't tip you off, look to the back wall where you will see tanks of live fish and lobster.  I wanted a tofu based dish however, so our very helpful waiter told me to try a dish of fried tofu with fresh mushrooms and Chinese broccoli, which I didn't see on the menu. He also recommended a dish of shrimp and scallops with Chinese long beans. Since it was cold outside, we also ordered winter melon soup, which is made from chicken broth and has bits of chopped pork and winter melon, which has a texture like cooked zucchini but is more flavorful. I couldn't resist this savory soup and ended up having two bowls before our main dishes came.  Our opinions were mixed on the latter. The fried tofu with mushrooms and broccoli was delicious, with the broccoli fried just right, not too raw and coarse or overcooked and soggy. The shrimp and scallops with long beans was salty and the beans tough, as if overcooked or picked past their season. The portions were large, and we received rice and tea as part of the meal. We were also offered dessert,  a choice of fruit with almond gelatin squares, or almond cookies. We declined these because we were so stuffed, but what we saw on the trays looked good. For all this food, we spent $35 plus 20 percent tip, as our waiter was exceptionally pleasant and attentive. I would recommend taking the 38 bus on Geary to get here however, as parking is sparse in this neighborhood, especially on a Sunday evening.
author: Eleanor T.
